Alla parter bidrar pÃ¥ olika sÃ¤tt till projektet., @xml:lang: SV, : The proportion of young people of the total population in Zambia is among the highest in the world and there are very few employment opportunities for the growing young population. This project aims to addressing the lack of productive employment for Zambian youth, in the transport, mining, construction, agriculture and forestry sectors. The goal of increasing employment opportunities for young people is achieved by developing modern curriculum for mechanics, in line with the needs of the private sector, offer relevant and demanded vocational training to students (focusing on disadvantaged and resource-poor youth) and strengthening the capacity of vocational training centers in Zambia. n nThe project is a phase two of a project that started in 2015. The goal was to establish a modern academy in collaboration with the Volvo Group, which could be offering the mining industry relevant vocational education programs and adequately educated students. The goal of the project was achieved as approximately 670 students were trained, a new national curriculum for Heavy Equipment Repair (HER) developed and capacities to deliver training in line with this curriculum were increased. n nBased on lessons learned from the first phase, the parties have agreed to continue the cooperation, but now focus more on the transport sector as there is a great need and the number of jobs available are more than those in the mining sector itself. Support to HER will however continue to a smaller extent and the training will be designed to suit also other important sectors. n nThe project is implemented, as in the first phase, as a collaboration between the private and public sectors, in a so-called Public Private Development Partnership. The strength of partnerships between private and public sectors lies mainly in the possibilities of translating the industry need for skilled labor into modern curricula, teaching materials, teacher training, relevant internships, etc. and thereby creating an education that meets the needs of the labour market and thus increase the employment opportunities for students. n nSida   the Embassy will contribute with SEK 12 million and Volvo with SEK 10 million, which can be compared to the previous phase for which Sida contributed SEK 12.9 million and Volvo with a bit over SEK 15 million. The project will be implemented for the period October 2019 to December 2022. n nUNIDO, the United Nations Industrial Development Agency, will lead the project implementation, as in the previous phase of the project. The project is being implemented at the NORTEC technical vocational school in Ndola and is supported by the Ministry of Higher Education and TEVETA, the national vocational training body. All parties support the project in different ways, @type: 2,  narrative: : Zambia is one of the youngest countries in Africa, with a youth population (15 to 35 years old) of 4.8 million (36.7% of the total population). In the economy, now in crisis, but even in years of economic growth, the participation is very unequal and poverty levels are high and employment creation low. Unemployment is one of the most pressing challenges for Zambian youth. Therefore, the Zambian government has set the goal of creating a million jobs over the next five years in key sectors in its 7th National Development Plan 2017-2021. Next to agriculture, the extractive and transport industries are the biggest employers. Zambia, a commodity-based landlocked economy, moves its extractive industry input and minerals output by road to the seaports of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania and Durban, South Africa. nIn the past twenty years, the production of copper has increased significantly. Even though the industry have faced and is facing fluctuating prices and other challenges Zambias mining industry has gained macroeconomic significance. nAlthough railway infrastructure is available, it needs substantial investment to comepte with the road connectivity available to all seven bordering countries. In order to support the government initiatives to bolster youth employment in key sectors, this project will enhance the transport and heavy equipment sector by fostering systemic change in the development of a skilled workforce. nThe majority of the current workforce acquires their skills through vocational institutions accredited by the Technical Education, Vocational and Entrepreneurship Training Authority Zambia (TEVETA). Due to the unavailability of industry linkages and funding constraints, most of these vocational institutions lack the appropriate infrastructure and modern equipment to provide their students with market relevant competencies. Because of this, even the graduates of these institutions are unable to find suitable employment, or, even if they do find work, have difficulty performing and retaining their jobs. The labour market operates with a sizeable expatriate workforce to fill this skills shortage, which affects the private sector bottom-line earnings because of the higher wage requirements of expatriate workers. nThis project aims to boost the capacity of a major vocational institution through a multilateral public-private partnership programme to decrease the skills shortage in transport truck sector. nThe overall objective of the project is to enhance youth employability in the transport and heavy duty equipment sector in Zambia. nThe outcome of the project is to provide effective and relevant industrial skills training to young Zambians; and help them transition into gainful employment by becoming more skilled, and therefore more employable. nThe following outputs and activities will take place under the proposed project: nOutput 1: Gap between employersâ€™ expectations and current educational standards for the transport and heavy equipment sector bridged through the development of a competency-based qualification framework and modern curriculum nActivity 1.1 Conduct a survey to determine curriculum input and labour data; nActivity 1.2 Develop a competency-based curriculum; nActivity 1.3 Validate the curriculum; nActivity 1.4 Obtain national accreditation for the new curriculum through TEVETA; n xa0 nOutput 2: Regional centre of excellence created by improving NORTECâ€™s institutional capacity through the provision of modern equipment and Training of Trainers (ToT) as well as scaling up across Zambia through the provision of relevant equipment and technology transfer trainings  nActivity 2.1 Upgrade existing NORTEC training facilities in the automotive department by procuring and installing modern equipment nActivity 2.2 Manufacture fixtures and accessories to handle the training equipment  machinery tools according to safe work practices; nActivity 2.3 Develop a staff development plan for conducting skills upgrading for all trainers in teaching methodologies and technical skills, including gender-sensitive approaches; nActivity 2.4 Provide trainers with technical and pedagogical skills necessary to deliver upgraded and new training curriculum (incl. e-Learning); xa0 nActivity 2.5 Identify VTCs across Zambia for knowledge-sharing and relevant technology transfer programme; nActivity 2.6 Determine relevant equipment, logistical support and budget for effective technology transfer; nActivity 2.7 Commission and deliver the relevant equipment and technology; nActivity 2.8 Deliver technology transfer sessions for other VTCs to equip trainers with technical and pedagogical skills necessary to deliver upgraded and new training curriculum n xa0 nOutput 3: Training and career services provided to 450 young Zambians, with a particular focus on female and disadvantaged students nActivity 3.1 Provide 450 young men and women with training programmes for the transport sector work force; nActivity 3.2 Promote gender equality through the dedicated and targeted actions to increase the enrolment of female students in a traditionally male-dominated industry; xa0 nActivity 3.3 Provide bursaries for vulnerable and underprivileged youth across Zambia to increase their participation in the training activities; xa0 nActivity 3.4 Establish a career services centre at NORTEC to help institute industry linkages to technical and soft-skills training and arrange professional and relevant internships for trainees; nActivity 3.5 Establish a performance management system to collect feedback from trainees doing company internships, from recent graduates as they transition into the workforce, and from employers hiring students, to ensure that the traineesâ€™ qualification meets companiesâ€™ needs

Description: More than one in three adult women globally have experienced physical or sexual violence by their intimate partner. We know that risk of intimate partner violence in adulthood for both women and men is linked to childhood and adolescent experiences of violence. However, less is known about why this is, particularly in low and middle-income countries. Most research on why comes from North America and Europe, where the basic patterns of childhood and adolescent violence exposure are different to many low and middle income country settings, including Uganda.  It is important to study why violence in childhood and adolescence and intimate partner violence in adulthood violence are linked so that we can figure out how to more effectively prevent violence across these time periods. Our study has three goals. The first is to get a better understanding of the patterns of prior violence exposure among young adolescents in Uganda, a low-income country setting. The second goal is to understand in more detail which types of violence exposure in early adolescence are associated with violence in later adolescence and young adulthood. The third is to explore how and why these associations occur, with a view to understanding how both characteristics of the individual, and characteristics of the contexts in which individuals find themselves, might amplify or interrupt these associations. In order to do this, we are intending to follow 3438 young adolescents over time. We plan to use a mixture of both survey methods with more in-depth interviews and observations to understand participants views and practices in relation to violence and experiences of growing up in Uganda.  We have already done one survey with young adolescents, their teachers and some of their caregivers in 2014, when the adolescents were aged 11-14 years. We will do a second survey in 2018, when the adolescents are aged 15-18 years, and a third survey in 2021 when they are 18-21 years. In our survey, we ask detailed questions about the use and experience of different forms of violence, the mental health of our participants, and about participants relationships with different types of people, including romantic relationships. We will gather extensive data on participants family, school, and other contexts where they spend time, and will analyse how these contexts can support the development of non-violent behaviour and relationships over time.  Our qualitative study will involve in-depth work with a sub-sample of about 36 girls and boys, who reported varying experiences of violence in the 2014 survey, when they were 11-14 years, and  who will also be followed up over time from 2018 until 2021. We will speak with these core participants individually, and with groups of friends, and conduct observations in and around the schools and communities where participants find themselves. Through building detailed biographical case studies with these young people, we hope to gain insight into how adolescents experience different forms of violence, and the ways in which their social relationships and networks influence their safety and perspectives and practices on violence.  As well as working with this core group, we will collect data from a broader sample of young people, school staff, parents, community members and officials, as well as the broader political and socio-economic landscape, in order to analyse the ways in which the contexts in which young people live enhance risks or help protect young people from violence. This research will improve understanding of what types of mechanisms we can target to help effectively prevent violence across adolescence and into adulthood. Our findings will be new and interesting because very few longitudinal studies have been conducted across this age group, and even fewer in low income country settings. We plan to use these results directly to develop programming in Uganda, @type: 2,  narrative: : Our main aims are: Aim 1. To examine the epidemiology and patterns of violence exposure in early adolescence.  Quantitatively we will document patterns of self-reported exposure to violence over time, combining information on physical, sexual and emotional violence and neglect, timing, frequency, severity and perpetrator, and the normative nature of the violence. Qualitatively we will explore how young people understand and interpret different forms and patterns of violence exposure, and what they perceive to be violence. Our hypotheses for quantitative analyses are: 1.1 There will be an underlying patterning of violence exposure at Waves 1, 2 and 3 1.2 The patterns groupings observed in Wave 1 will persist at Wave 2 and Wave 3 Aim 2 (Main aim for quantitative study). To understand which patterns of early adolescent exposure to violence are associated with violence use and experience in later adolescence and young adulthood. We will explore the magnitude of the association between different patterns of early adolescent violence exposure and late adolescent and early adult outcomes. Qualitatively, we will explore how young peoples subjectivities, including their values, beliefs and practices, shape their responses to and are shaped by earlier experiences of different patterns of violence. Our hypothesis for quantitative analysis is: 2.1 The likelihood of use and experience of intimate partner violence at Wave 3 will differ by Wave 1 violence exposure group Aim 3. To explore the pathways by which violence in early adolescence, later adolescence and young adulthood are associated, and how context encourages or interrupts these associations. Quantitatively, we will explore whether exposure to specific individual and contextual factors mediate or moderate the relationship between early exposures and later use and experience of violence. Qualitatively, we aim to explore how family, peer and intimate partner relationships influence young peoples responses to violence over time, including their capacity to stay safe and to sustain equitable beliefs. We will examine how school systems, practices and relationships influence girls and boys capacity to build or maintain anti-violence norms and practices over time, and how transitions to secondary school or out of school influence these processes. We will explore how community structures, norms and relationships, including religious and community justice systems, local provision of services, community organisations and access to media influence girls and boys perspectives and practices regarding violence. We will consider how the political economy of the macro-level context influences these processes. Our hypotheses for quantitative analysis are: 3.1 Being male or female will moderate the association between Wave 1 violence exposure and Wave 3 intimate partner violence use and experience  3.2 Whether Wave 1 violence exposure is considered socially normative will moderate the association between Wave 1 violence exposure and Wave 3 intimate partner violence use and experience  3.3 Mental health status at Wave 2 will mediate the association between Wave 1 violence exposure and Wave 3 intimate partner violence use and experience 3.4 Having a family with no violence between caregivers and no caregiver mental health issues at Wave 2 will mediate the association between Wave 1 violence exposure and Wave 3 intimate partner violence use and experience  3.5 Being more exposed to the Good School Toolkit will mediate the association between Wave 1 violence exposure and Wave 3 intimate partner violence use and experience  3.6 Staying in school will mediate the association between Wave 1 violence exposure and Wave 3 intimate partner violence use and experience We plan to explore other factors which may affect the relationship between early adolescent violence exposures and and later outcomes, using an ecosocial approach (these are outlined in Figure 2 of our Case for Support)
Organizations: ['UK - Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy', 'UK Research & Innovation']

Description: The project aims at addressing different aspects of women leadership in the PCU Churches. While there are few theological or structural hindrances for women in leadership in PCU, there are still socio-cultural norms that PCU wants to see challenged and changed. In the participation of the leadership and management training, affirmative action will be taken to ensure women participation
Organizations: ['Digni', 'Norad - Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation', 'Norwegian Government', 'Pentacostal Churches of Uganda']

Description: ENABLE: Higher Education and Multimedia in Special Needs Education and Rehabilitation aims to build the capacity for special needs education at three universties in East Africa; Kyambogo University, University of Dar Es Salaam and Kenya Institute of Special Education, as well as University of Oslo
Organizations: ['Kyambogo University', 'Kyambogo University', 'Norad - Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation', 'Norwegian Government']

Description: The project aims to contribute to reduced greenhouse gas emissions and improved ecosystem health for sustainable livelihoods in Eastern Africa by strengthening the capacity for education and research on climate change and REDD+ at Makerere University and the University of Dar es Salaam (UDSM), in partnership with the University of Life Sciences (UMB) in Norway
Organizations: ['Makerere University', 'Makerere University', 'Norad - Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation', 'Norwegian Government']

Description: Programme activities to transform social, cultural and gender norms for reduction of violence against children, including child marriage and teenage pregnancy, also with a focus on returning married girls and teenage mothers to school. Other partners: Uganda Women Action Program (UWAP), WoMena, National Union for Disabled People in Uganda (NUDIPU), Building Community Initiatives for Development (BIDs), Uganda Child Rights NGO Network (UCRNN)
Organizations: ['Norad - Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation', 'Norwegian Government', 'Redd Barna Norge', 'Undefined']

Description: NRC is Norwayâ€™s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida s Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC s capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida s humanitarian unit s annual budget appropriation which is substantial. nThe objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. nNRCâ€™s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. xa0Sida s Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC s method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). nMore specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras El Salvador Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. nAs an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: xa026% for Shelter and settlements, xa020% for xa0 Education, xa017% for Livelihoods and Food Security, xa014% for ICLA, xa09% for WASH, xa03% for Camp Management and xa011% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. nThe good scores of NRC in ITAD s evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. nDescribing NRC s activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC s work. xa0 nSHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC s expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in xa0protracted displacement situations. nLIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. That was a contribution to reduce dependency on aid, prevent criminality and violence, enhance social cohesion and at the same time preparing the way for durable solutions to displacement situation. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life xa0and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten xa0livelihoods and individuals  and households  abilities to earn a living. nICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one s rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. Advising on divorce procedures, supporting women to claim their rights while separating from men they had been married to in early marriage arrangements, was a significant work of NRC s lawyers. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to people to claim xa0and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative xa0dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity xa0documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge xa0around migration laws. Specific assistance to women and children as they may face xa0particular obstacles in accessing their rights. nEDUCATION: Children and youth lose years of education due to displacement. NRC works for reintegrating students in schools by helping them catching up lost grades faster. NRC has been training teachers and school personnel in Burundi to absorb the additional numbers of returnee youth who were Burundian refugees born in Tanzania that are enrolling in ill-prepared Burundian schools, at the best interest of the students, including protection aspects. Students had to be assisted for shifting overnight from Kiswahili and English-language curriculas to Kirundi and French-language curriculas. By doing that NRC, not only restaures education rights, but contributes to the local social cohesion. NRC is involved in the global Education Cannot Wait through advocacy. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to children and youth to complete a full cycle of basic education xa0with particular focus on those who are out of school or have had their education xa0interrupted. Provision of technical and vocational training for young adults. nCAMP MANAGEMENT: NRC showed further its protection work to Sida in Azraq and Zaatari refugee camps in Jordan, designed for accommodating social cases, un-documented individuals and alleged security threats, including un-accompanied minors, who could not be left free in the society according to the authorities. NRC would turn the experience of detention, in the middle of nowhere, desertic in fact, less depressing by upgrading shelter conditions, and providing education services, vocational training and psychosocial support, including assisting refugees to negotiate temporary exit permits. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Camp management, in and outside of camp settings. Camp xa0management core functions include coordinating and monitoring assistance and xa0protection, setting up and supporting governance and community participation xa0mechanisms, managing and disseminating information, providing multisector feedback xa0mechanisms, and maintaining infrastructure. nWASH: Five year into their displacement situation, Syrian refugees in Lebanon were still provided with 15 L person day drinkable water through costly water-trucking deliveries serving around 285,000 people living in thousands of informal tented settlements (ITS) of the Bekaa valley. Central authorities were blocking any improvements, like drilling wells, that would result in permanenting the refugee settlements in the country or giving the refugees the hope that they have a future in Lebanon. NRC managed to negotiate with communal councils, eager to improve their own infrastructures needing maintainance since the Civil War, that certain settlements along main roads would be connected to the local water systems. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of infrastructre for xa0water and sanitation, and information dissemination on good hygiene practices. nSida has evidence that NRC is aligning fully its own response strategies on the HRPs, which is a condition for receiving Sida s funding. NRC is usually an active stakeholder of the process of elaborating such plans, inter alia through its engagement in participating in or co-leading clusters of the local humanitarian system (potentially in its core competencies sectors) depending on locations, and through hosting NGO coordination forums. xa0 nRRM Allocation 2021 nIncluded in this contribution, it is proposed to support NRC s capacity to address new emerging humanitarian needs in rapid onset crises. Sida s funding Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) allocation to NRC will enable NRC to react very fast to new disasters when they strike. It may provide seed funding to larger response programmes and catalyze more resources, complementing as well the resources that the flexibility of PBA provides for re-allocating them in such circumstances, when possible. In 2020, NRC tapped into its 50 MSEK allocation 15 times, replenished once, until it was exhausted, intervening in 13 countries where NRC had presence in the context of sudden displacement situations, floods, droughts and socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 on displaced and vulnerable households. The assistance provided consisted generally in protection services and assistance delivered in form of cash, vouchers, and in-kind life-saving commodities, in the areas of shelter, basic assistance kits, hygiene promotion and psychosocial support. In 2021, NRC will undertake similar interventions with the RRM allocation with an initial 40 MSEK funding from Sida. RRM interventions are considered as projects, implemented over a 3 to 6 month period, with a 3 MSEK budget in average. The ceiling is 5 MSEK, while the bottom budget is 2 MSEK, but exceptions can be justified case by case. nMethod- and capacity-building projects nIncluded in this contribution, NRC has proposed to Sida to support Method- and capacity-building projects that will contribute to improve the global humanitarian system and coordination & advocacy forums at the national level. n- Strengthening global protection policy for displacement communities is a project that Sida is willing to prioritize as it xa0focuses on ensuring effective integration of protection across NRC programming and improvements to global humanitarian protection policy by translating concepts into concrete actionable outcomes. This project aims at ensuring that protection is foundational to all NRC work through the â€˜Safe Programmingâ€™ framework defining minimum commitments for NRC s operations, and at supporting the full realisation of the right of freedom of movement in safety and dignity for displacement-affected persons, in programmes for the protection of civilians, for durable solutions and for migrants in  refugee-like  situations. n- Becoming the leading displacement organization in hard to reach areas (H2R) is a project that will be supported in 2021 by Sida. It addresses the growing complexity of operating environments by investing in in-depth understanding of contexts against the backdrop of shifting international norms and the rise of new tech solutions to ensure timely and appropriate responses. NRC wants to xa0ensure that displacement-affected individuals considered hard-to-reach have better access to assistance and protection, by enhancing NRC s ability to access multiple geographical and cultural H2R contexts, by delivering high quality and sustained programming in H2R areas and by advocating for the rights of people affected by displacement in H2R areas. n- Sida s support to NRC s CashCap will be continued in 2021. The project ensures that humanitarian development agencies and national actors have sufficient and sustained expertise to design and implement cash and market-based response (CMBR) in an effective and coordinated manner. NRC intends to ensure global rapid deployment capacity for the initial days of a sudden onset emergency and to enable the systematic consideration of cash and voucher assistance as part of the initial response analysis. NRC will facilitate knowledge exchange, provide technical backstop and support to CashCap roster members on deployment, and improve sustainability between CashCap expert and cash community by sharing information, promoting continuity and encouraging to take ownership by the cash community. n- xa0NRCâ€™s Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) in Geneva will continue to be co-financed by Sida s humanitarian unit and Sida s unit for Global Cooperation on Environment in 2021. IDMC is a global leader in monitoring, reporting on and advocating for people displaced within their own country. It is known for its research publications and advocacy aiming at xa0generating evidence on all situations of internal displacement; building capacity to prevent and respond to the issue; and galvanising political commitment and action to drive positive change. For the second and probably last year, Sida s Unit for Global Cooperation on Environment will co-finance IDMC in 2021 together with the Humanitarian Unit, as IDMC analyzes displacement situation trends caused by climate change as well. IDMC adds great value to the evidence- and needs-based mobilization of resources for displacement situations. Its analysis and research are major contributions to the global and local advocacy agenda. n- NRC will be supported as well through this contribution for hosting local humanitarian coordination platforms where international and local NGOs cooperate for building up coordinated programmes, common advocacy agendas and for influencing the policy-making of authorities, the UN, donors and other partners. These forums play a key role in localizing the response, offering coordination services, training and partnership opportunities to the local NGO community. They play as well an important role for INGOs in addressing administrative and access obstacles that they may face with authorities for establishing themselves and obtaining visas and work permits. The Jordan INGO Forum and the Libya INGO Forum will be supported through this contribution. xa0NRC s active engagement in the local NGO forums, sometimes by hosting them with Sida s support (DRC, Palestine (AIDA), Jordan, Libya, Lebanon until (2019)), demonstrates NRC s commitment to aid effectiveness and collective action regarding humanitarian coordination and advocacy. n- Furthermore, it is proposed to continue co-financing for a last year the West Bank Protection Consortium (WBPC) with the Swedish General Consulate in Jerusalem and other donors. It is a strategic partnership between DG ECHO, 10 European States and 5 INGOs providing protection and assistance to Palestinians at risk of forcible transfer in the West Bank due to recurrent violations of international law. The project addresses the protection needs of persons and communities of concern through a multi-sector approach that reduces vulnerabilities, builds capacities and responds to threats. The Consulate has established a 3 year partnership 2021-2023 with NRC (#14571, 39 MSEK) for that project. The WBPC project, and the NGO platform AIDA, supported so far by Sida s humanitarian unit, will be funded by Sweden s development cooperation strategy for Palestine, integrated in that contribution., @xml:lang: EN}]}, {@type: 1,  narrative: [{: Norwegian Refugee Council - Norska flyktingrÃ¥det (NRC) - har ansÃ¶kt om ett fÃ¶rnyat partnerskap med Sida 2021-2025. NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out â€œthe Humanitarian Programme for 2021â€ in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine,  Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. The application includes provision of 40 million SEK to replenish the Rapid Response Mechanism funding instrument and 7 individual projects for method, capacity-building and coordination. n nThe objectives of NRCâ€™s intervention is to protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. NRCs principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021. n nNRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRCs programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus. n nNRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.  n nThe interventionâ€™s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sidaâ€™s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR,  etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach â€“ PBA). n nHumanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus nNRCs catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRCs advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRCs analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRCs portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Swedens development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.  n n1.2 MSEK is granted in June 2021 for supporting the IASCs review of the implementation of the IASC protection policy, through a 10 month consultancy hosted by NRC. n n40 MSEK are granted to NRC in Colombia and Venezuela regions (5+5 MSEK), Mali (5 MSEK), Mozambique (7.5 MSEK), Niger (7.5 MSEK) and Syria (10 MSEK) in June 2021 as reserve allocations to escalating and or under-funding crises. Mozambique is a new context for NRC. n n65 MSEK are granted to NRC in Dr Congo (10 MSEK), South Sudan (10 MSEK), Sudan (20 MSEK) and Syria (25 MSEK) in October 2021 as a end of the year allocation to escalating and underfunded crises., @xml:lang: EN}]}]

Description: The development objective of the First Phase of the Mining Governance and Development Project for Togo is to streamline the institutional arrangements of key organizations in the extractive industries to strengthen their efficiency and accountability for effective management of the sector. The project comprises of three components. The first component, mining governance, transparency, oversight, and efficiency will support enhanced management and monitoring of mineral development activities in Togo, starting from licensing of initial exploration activities to supervision of mining and eventual mine closure. It consists of following six sub-components: (i) mining cadastre and national geological database; (ii) transaction advisory services for assessment of mineral development proposals; (iii) mineral production monitoring and oversight; (iv) organizational development of the ministry of mines and energy (MME); (v) strengthening of corporate governance structures of state-owned enterprises (SOEs) in the mining industry; and (vi) management of artisanal and small-scale mining (ASM). The second component, environmental, social, and economic development from mining operations objective is to support conditions for mining sector activities to contribute to sustainable socioeconomic development. It consists of following three sub-components: (i) higher education sector support and public access to information about mineral development; (ii) environmental and social management of mining operations and support to community development platforms; and (iii) infrastructure and economic linkages from mining. The third component, project management and coordination, including preparatory project financing will support the project implementation unit (PIU), based in the MME, in the management of fiduciary, disbursement, monitoring and evaluation (M and E), and other project impleme
Organizations: ['International Development Association', 'International Development Association', 'MINISTRY OF MINES', 'MINISTRY OF MINES']

Description: The  project will enhance capacity at higher education institutions in Tanzania (the University of Dar es Salaam) and Zanzibar (the State University of Zanzibar) on climate change in relation to vulnerability and resilience of coastal ecosystems and communities. The focus is on coastal resource governance, community access, control, and rights to coastal resources, participation in decision-making, and gender roles in coastal Tanzania and Zanzibar

Description: NRC is Norwayâ€™s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida s Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC s capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida s humanitarian unit s annual budget appropriation which is substantial. nThe objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. nNRCâ€™s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. xa0Sida s Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC s method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). nMore specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras El Salvador Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. nAs an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: xa026% for Shelter and settlements, xa020% for xa0 Education, xa017% for Livelihoods and Food Security, xa014% for ICLA, xa09% for WASH, xa03% for Camp Management and xa011% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. nThe good scores of NRC in ITAD s evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. nDescribing NRC s activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC s work. xa0 nSHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC s expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in xa0protracted displacement situations. nLIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. That was a contribution to reduce dependency on aid, prevent criminality and violence, enhance social cohesion and at the same time preparing the way for durable solutions to displacement situation. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life xa0and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten xa0livelihoods and individuals  and households  abilities to earn a living. nICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one s rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. Advising on divorce procedures, supporting women to claim their rights while separating from men they had been married to in early marriage arrangements, was a significant work of NRC s lawyers. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to people to claim xa0and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative xa0dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity xa0documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge xa0around migration laws. Specific assistance to women and children as they may face xa0particular obstacles in accessing their rights. nEDUCATION: Children and youth lose years of education due to displacement. NRC works for reintegrating students in schools by helping them catching up lost grades faster. NRC has been training teachers and school personnel in Burundi to absorb the additional numbers of returnee youth who were Burundian refugees born in Tanzania that are enrolling in ill-prepared Burundian schools, at the best interest of the students, including protection aspects. Students had to be assisted for shifting overnight from Kiswahili and English-language curriculas to Kirundi and French-language curriculas. By doing that NRC, not only restaures education rights, but contributes to the local social cohesion. NRC is involved in the global Education Cannot Wait through advocacy. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to children and youth to complete a full cycle of basic education xa0with particular focus on those who are out of school or have had their education xa0interrupted. Provision of technical and vocational training for young adults. nCAMP MANAGEMENT: NRC showed further its protection work to Sida in Azraq and Zaatari refugee camps in Jordan, designed for accommodating social cases, un-documented individuals and alleged security threats, including un-accompanied minors, who could not be left free in the society according to the authorities. NRC would turn the experience of detention, in the middle of nowhere, desertic in fact, less depressing by upgrading shelter conditions, and providing education services, vocational training and psychosocial support, including assisting refugees to negotiate temporary exit permits. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Camp management, in and outside of camp settings. Camp xa0management core functions include coordinating and monitoring assistance and xa0protection, setting up and supporting governance and community participation xa0mechanisms, managing and disseminating information, providing multisector feedback xa0mechanisms, and maintaining infrastructure. nWASH: Five year into their displacement situation, Syrian refugees in Lebanon were still provided with 15 L person day drinkable water through costly water-trucking deliveries serving around 285,000 people living in thousands of informal tented settlements (ITS) of the Bekaa valley. Central authorities were blocking any improvements, like drilling wells, that would result in permanenting the refugee settlements in the country or giving the refugees the hope that they have a future in Lebanon. NRC managed to negotiate with communal councils, eager to improve their own infrastructures needing maintainance since the Civil War, that certain settlements along main roads would be connected to the local water systems. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of infrastructre for xa0water and sanitation, and information dissemination on good hygiene practices. nSida has evidence that NRC is aligning fully its own response strategies on the HRPs, which is a condition for receiving Sida s funding. NRC is usually an active stakeholder of the process of elaborating such plans, inter alia through its engagement in participating in or co-leading clusters of the local humanitarian system (potentially in its core competencies sectors) depending on locations, and through hosting NGO coordination forums. xa0 nRRM Allocation 2021 nIncluded in this contribution, it is proposed to support NRC s capacity to address new emerging humanitarian needs in rapid onset crises. Sida s funding Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) allocation to NRC will enable NRC to react very fast to new disasters when they strike. It may provide seed funding to larger response programmes and catalyze more resources, complementing as well the resources that the flexibility of PBA provides for re-allocating them in such circumstances, when possible. In 2020, NRC tapped into its 50 MSEK allocation 15 times, replenished once, until it was exhausted, intervening in 13 countries where NRC had presence in the context of sudden displacement situations, floods, droughts and socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 on displaced and vulnerable households. The assistance provided consisted generally in protection services and assistance delivered in form of cash, vouchers, and in-kind life-saving commodities, in the areas of shelter, basic assistance kits, hygiene promotion and psychosocial support. In 2021, NRC will undertake similar interventions with the RRM allocation with an initial 40 MSEK funding from Sida. RRM interventions are considered as projects, implemented over a 3 to 6 month period, with a 3 MSEK budget in average. The ceiling is 5 MSEK, while the bottom budget is 2 MSEK, but exceptions can be justified case by case. nMethod- and capacity-building projects nIncluded in this contribution, NRC has proposed to Sida to support Method- and capacity-building projects that will contribute to improve the global humanitarian system and coordination & advocacy forums at the national level. n- Strengthening global protection policy for displacement communities is a project that Sida is willing to prioritize as it xa0focuses on ensuring effective integration of protection across NRC programming and improvements to global humanitarian protection policy by translating concepts into concrete actionable outcomes. This project aims at ensuring that protection is foundational to all NRC work through the â€˜Safe Programmingâ€™ framework defining minimum commitments for NRC s operations, and at supporting the full realisation of the right of freedom of movement in safety and dignity for displacement-affected persons, in programmes for the protection of civilians, for durable solutions and for migrants in  refugee-like  situations. n- Becoming the leading displacement organization in hard to reach areas (H2R) is a project that will be supported in 2021 by Sida. It addresses the growing complexity of operating environments by investing in in-depth understanding of contexts against the backdrop of shifting international norms and the rise of new tech solutions to ensure timely and appropriate responses. NRC wants to xa0ensure that displacement-affected individuals considered hard-to-reach have better access to assistance and protection, by enhancing NRC s ability to access multiple geographical and cultural H2R contexts, by delivering high quality and sustained programming in H2R areas and by advocating for the rights of people affected by displacement in H2R areas. n- Sida s support to NRC s CashCap will be continued in 2021. The project ensures that humanitarian development agencies and national actors have sufficient and sustained expertise to design and implement cash and market-based response (CMBR) in an effective and coordinated manner. NRC intends to ensure global rapid deployment capacity for the initial days of a sudden onset emergency and to enable the systematic consideration of cash and voucher assistance as part of the initial response analysis. NRC will facilitate knowledge exchange, provide technical backstop and support to CashCap roster members on deployment, and improve sustainability between CashCap expert and cash community by sharing information, promoting continuity and encouraging to take ownership by the cash community. n- xa0NRCâ€™s Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) in Geneva will continue to be co-financed by Sida s humanitarian unit and Sida s unit for Global Cooperation on Environment in 2021. IDMC is a global leader in monitoring, reporting on and advocating for people displaced within their own country. It is known for its research publications and advocacy aiming at xa0generating evidence on all situations of internal displacement; building capacity to prevent and respond to the issue; and galvanising political commitment and action to drive positive change. For the second and probably last year, Sida s Unit for Global Cooperation on Environment will co-finance IDMC in 2021 together with the Humanitarian Unit, as IDMC analyzes displacement situation trends caused by climate change as well. IDMC adds great value to the evidence- and needs-based mobilization of resources for displacement situations. Its analysis and research are major contributions to the global and local advocacy agenda. n- NRC will be supported as well through this contribution for hosting local humanitarian coordination platforms where international and local NGOs cooperate for building up coordinated programmes, common advocacy agendas and for influencing the policy-making of authorities, the UN, donors and other partners. These forums play a key role in localizing the response, offering coordination services, training and partnership opportunities to the local NGO community. They play as well an important role for INGOs in addressing administrative and access obstacles that they may face with authorities for establishing themselves and obtaining visas and work permits. The Jordan INGO Forum and the Libya INGO Forum will be supported through this contribution. xa0NRC s active engagement in the local NGO forums, sometimes by hosting them with Sida s support (DRC, Palestine (AIDA), Jordan, Libya, Lebanon until (2019)), demonstrates NRC s commitment to aid effectiveness and collective action regarding humanitarian coordination and advocacy. n- Furthermore, it is proposed to continue co-financing for a last year the West Bank Protection Consortium (WBPC) with the Swedish General Consulate in Jerusalem and other donors. It is a strategic partnership between DG ECHO, 10 European States and 5 INGOs providing protection and assistance to Palestinians at risk of forcible transfer in the West Bank due to recurrent violations of international law. The project addresses the protection needs of persons and communities of concern through a multi-sector approach that reduces vulnerabilities, builds capacities and responds to threats. The Consulate has established a 3 year partnership 2021-2023 with NRC (#14571, 39 MSEK) for that project. The WBPC project, and the NGO platform AIDA, supported so far by Sida s humanitarian unit, will be funded by Sweden s development cooperation strategy for Palestine, integrated in that contribution., @xml:lang: EN}]}, {@type: 1,  narrative: [{: Norwegian Refugee Council - Norska flyktingrÃ¥det (NRC) - har ansÃ¶kt om ett fÃ¶rnyat partnerskap med Sida 2021-2025. NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out â€œthe Humanitarian Programme for 2021â€ in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine,  Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. The application includes provision of 40 million SEK to replenish the Rapid Response Mechanism funding instrument and 7 individual projects for method, capacity-building and coordination. n nThe objectives of NRCâ€™s intervention is to protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. NRCs principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021. n nNRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRCs programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus. n nNRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.  n nThe interventionâ€™s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sidaâ€™s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR,  etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach â€“ PBA). n nHumanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus nNRCs catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRCs advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRCs analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRCs portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Swedens development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.  n n1.2 MSEK is granted in June 2021 for supporting the IASCs review of the implementation of the IASC protection policy, through a 10 month consultancy hosted by NRC. n n40 MSEK are granted to NRC in Colombia and Venezuela regions (5+5 MSEK), Mali (5 MSEK), Mozambique (7.5 MSEK), Niger (7.5 MSEK) and Syria (10 MSEK) in June 2021 as reserve allocations to escalating and or under-funding crises. Mozambique is a new context for NRC. n n65 MSEK are granted to NRC in Dr Congo (10 MSEK), South Sudan (10 MSEK), Sudan (20 MSEK) and Syria (25 MSEK) in October 2021 as a end of the year allocation to escalating and underfunded crises., @xml:lang: EN}]}]

RÃ¤dda Barnen fortsÃ¤tter att arbeta i partnerskap men kommer ocksÃ¥ att Ã¶vervÃ¤ga att jobba med nya partners nÃ¤r det bedÃ¶ms mer effektivt., @xml:lang: SV, : The intervention (Save the Children Country Strategic Plan 2019-2021) intends to reach 722,950 most deprived children in ten regions in Tanzania i.e. (Dar es Salaam, Dodoma, Katavi, Kigoma, Shinyanga, Singida, Songwe, Rukwa, Tabora, and Zanzibar) by 2021 with various services i.e. child protection, health and nutrition, education, and good governance. It will also engage with 32,300 stakeholders in monitoring and demanding child rights, promoting coordinated actions for child protection systems, providing basic education and participating in discussions on public investment in children. Furthermore, it will work to ensure that policies and national resources established as an outcome of its programming are designed to benefit the most deprived. SC intends to measure its results in terms of the tangible improvements it makes in the lives of the most deprived children. For example,in the previous phase of support, Save the Children has played an important role in building public awareness on the issue of child marriage at community level. Therefore based on the experience from previous support the Embassy is developing a new support to Save the Children. Furthermore, based on results seen during the previous phase of support 2016 - 2018, the Embassy is developing this support before the External Evaluation of the SC Country Strategic Plan 2016-2018 has been completed. The recommendations from the external evaluation will be followed up during followup dialogue with the organisation. nSave the Children developed its Theory of Change framework by combining 4 pillars in order to create impact for children in all its programmes. The four pillars of the Theory of Change are: n1) Save the Children (SC) aims to be the Voice of advocating and campaigning for better practices and policies to fulfill childrens rights and to ensure that childrens voices are heard. Save the Children is an organisation fighting to acheive childrens rights, particularly for the poorest and most marginalised children, who are at risks of their rights being denied. n2) Save the children will be the Innovator for developing and providing evidence based, replicable solutions to problems facing children. The organisation intends to promote durable soultions, including innovative approaches that create breakthrough improvements for children at national and community level. This requires testing interventions, documenting results and evaluating impact, so that the work contributes to global evidence about how to acheive important changes for children. n3) Save the Children aims to acheive results at scale by supporting effective implementation of best practices, programs and policies for children, by leveraging knowledge to ensure sustainable impact at scale. This will be done by engaging other change agents, and by encouraging an environment conducive to positive development. n4) Save the Children will build partnerships through collaborating with children, civil society organisations, communities, government and the private sector to share knowledge, influence others and build capacity to ensure childrens rights are met. In order to effectively implement its innovations and achieve results at scale, SC will continously identify partners and build appropriate relationships and networks for programming, policy, advocacy and campaigns. n nThe SC Theory of change cuts across the 2019-2021 Country Strategy Plan, with all pillars of the ToC outlined in each strategic goal of the Tanzania Country Programme.  During this period, SC will continue to focus on its key programmatic strengths which include Child Protection, Child Rights Governance, Health and Nutrition and Education with an intensified focus on documenting and sharing the results of its innovations. Save the Children will continue working in partnerships but will also assess some of its on-going partnership arrangements to ensure that they share the same values with SC and complement each others strengths, @type: 2,  narrative: : The development intervention envisions a world in which every child attains the right to survival, protection, development and participation. The mission of the development intervention is to inspire changes in the way the world treats children, and to achieve immediate and lasting change in their lives. The development intervention has identified intentions at Global level that are to be translated at national level. The global intentions 2030 are 1) Survive: No Child dies from preventable causes before their 5th birthday 2) Learn: all Children learn from a quality basic education and 3) Be protected: Violence against Children is no longer tolerated. nThe intervention intends to reach 722,950 most deprived children in ten regions in Tanzania i.e. (Dar es Salaam, Dodoma, Katavi, Kigoma, Shinyanga, Singida, Songwe, Rukwa, Tabora, and Zanzibar) by 2021 with various services i.e. child protection, health, education, and good governance. It will also engage with 32,300 stakeholders in monitoring and demanding child rights, promoting coordinated actions for child protection systems, providing basic education and participating in discussions on public investment in children. Furthermore, it will work to ensure that policies and national resources established as an outcome of its programming are designed to benefit the most deprived. SC intends to measure its results in terms of the tangible improvements it makes in the lives of the most deprived children. nSave the Childrens Tanzania Country Programme will continue to focus on its five key programmatic areas i.e. Child Protection, Child Rights Governance, Health and Nutrition, Education with an increased focus of documenting and sharing the results of various innovations. A gender audit performed in 2018 will determine the different gender needs within the organisation. Based on the gender audit, the current programming will have an increased focus on the different gender needs of its beneficiaries for example in Child Protection, the interventions will include engagement of men and boys to challenge the values and norms around negative masculinities and female dominated parenting, community dialogues on gender based norms that are harmful to children and women as well as the roles of fathers and men to protect boys and girls. Staff will also be trained and mentored in the Save the Children Gender Equity Programme Guidance and Toolkit which would enable them to become more effective in followup of results with a gender lens. xa0Gender equality will be mainstreamed across all strategic goals. The Embassy will followup the acheivements attained during the previous support through the external evaluation of the SC Country Strategy Plan 2016 - 2018. nThe strategic goals of the programme in Tanzania will be: n1) Improved accountability by the Government to fulfill child rights in Tanzania- this is the central core of child rights governance to SC work and its collaborators in Tanzania. n2) Children are protected from all forms of violence- there is a high prevalence of violence which is experienced by chidlren throughout the country. The policy environment to adress this issue is favourable despite the political environment being challenging. n3) Children involved in or at risk of harmful work, including refugees and migrants, are able to access protection services- Migrant and refugee children, most often at risk of participating in harmful work, are some of the most vulnerable children in Tanzania. the vast majority of these children do not receive any protection services from the state or civil society. n4) Children ages 0-13 demonstrate age appropriate learning outcomes- xa0 Early childhood and basic education is an underlying issue to other strategic goals that have been prioritised. n5) Children below five years consume an appropriate quantity and quality of foods to meet their dietary needs during all times of the year- Favourable policy environment and critical period ( first 1000 days) to ensure children can acheive their full potential. n6) Adolescent pregnancies are reduced through improved services, legal framework and education on girls rights- Although the policy environment is not favourable, there is a need to be bold and ensure that adolescent girls, including young mothers, can fulfill their rights n7) Increased access to and coverage of high impact maternal and newborn interventions- this is core to SC work, and aligns with expertise in the Tanzania Country Programme. nThe existence of child rights networks and forums in Tanzania is considered to be an opportunity for implementing and monitoring child rights issues, although there could be a challenge in coordination for recommendations for key international instruments such as the UNCRC. xa0The development intervention intends to lead by example and act as a voice for transparency and acoountability in its Child rights work, especially as a catalyst for engagement and strengthening of civil society to defend Child rights
Organizations: ['Save the Children - donor country office', 'Save the Children, Sweden', 'Sweden', 'Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency']

Description: The project seeks to fulfill five key objectives: n1. Support national longitudinal quantitative and qualitative impact evaluation of government-owned and implemented cash transfer and integrated social protection programmes in the region in order to: understand programme impacts, and the role of design and implementation features and pathways through which impacts are achieved; n2. Generate evidence that supports national efforts to build risk-informed and shock-responsive social protection systems, including national registries and delivery mechanisms that facilitate effective and rapid vertical and horizontal expansions; n3. Support national efforts to build investment cases and identify sustainable financing for building statutory cash transfer and social protection programmes; n4. Undertake cross-country and cross-regional analysis to respond to evidence gaps on social transfer programmes and social protection systems in the region n5. Facilitate mechanisms for learning and exchange among regional policy makers, implementers, researchers and civil society â€“ through workshops, web resources, public data availability, and open-access publications. nProposed outputs will include primary data collection, reports, manuscripts for peer-reviewed publication, policy and research briefs and infographics animations to translate findings, engagement with policymakers, and dissemination via social media, peer-reviewed journals, capacity building for African researchers and international conference presentations. nComments xa0 nThere is ongoing work in Ethiopia, Tanzania and Burkina Faso. These three countries are earmarked to receive continued support for 2021 and 2022. xa0 nIn the East and Southern African region there is more interest in evidence related to the role of design and implementation in achieving impacts. In West and Central Africa, where social protection programmes are not as widely established, basic impact evaluations are is still required to make the case for investing in cash transfers and social protection programmes. nProposed topics for potential secondary analyses (including cross-country comparisons) and in-depth papers: Impacts of cash-transfer programmes on education, time use and safe-transition to adulthood using data from Malawi, Ethiopia and Ghana. Impacts of cash transfers on food-group elasticities. Comparison of social cash transfer beneficiaries with ultra-poor populations within countries nTopics of other outputs related to dissemination (briefs, blogs, social media, presentations) will be determined by the aforementioned data collections and papers finalized, as well as invitations received related to international meetings on an annual basis. nThe Transfer Project workshop (held approximately every two years) is a key capacity building activity for researchers, policymakers, and development partners alike and is jointly convened by all three Transfer Project partners. The workshop provides a space for the researchers, practitioners, policymakers, national and international partners to engage with each other and helps to increase the understanding of evidence. It also provides an impetus for other countries to demand rigorous evidence generation in their own countries, or to study previously understudied questions in their own context by exposure to what researchers are doing elsewhere. xa0 nFinally, UNICEF Innocenti will convene sub-regional webinars that promote evidence exchange between neighboring countries. Participants will include government officials, national research partners, Swedish Embassies, other development partners and academic researchers, @type: 1,  narrative: : UNICEF s center for research and evidence generation, Innocenti, has requested Sida to support the implementation of research in the Transfer Project - third phase with the amount of SEK 24 000 000. n nThe project shall contribute to longitudinal quantitative and qualitative evaluations of the effects of social protection systems with cash transfers in government led programs for social cash transfers.  The purpose is to generate evidence that can be used for future ndecisions on policy and further development of national systems for social protection in nAfrica. n nThe project will be implemented during 2021-2024 and aims to achieve five goals, these are that:  n n1.
