Description: The United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAP) in Tanzania is designed to strengthen the co-ordination and effectiveness of the UN system at national level, as a contribution to Tanzania s efforts to achieve sustainable poverty reduction and the implementation of human rights. The broad business corresponds to several of the goals set out in the Swedish Development Cooperation Development Strategy Tanzania 2013-2019. Four out of twelve results areas are particularly relevant to the Swedish strategy: good governance   human rights   gender; violence against women and children; female participation and political leadership; as well as economic growth and employment. The Swedish strategy identifies women, children and adolescents as prioritized target groups, which also reflects well in the areas of support chosen by Sida. n nUNDAP II is fully in line with the donors  Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) and with Tanzania s National Visions (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). UNDAP II is also developed in line with Tanzania s five-year plan 2015 16 - 2020 21 and with global sustainability and development goals. Den breda verksamheten motsvarar flera av de mÃ¥l som anges i den svenska resultatstrategin fÃ¶r utvecklingssamarbetet med Tanzania 2013-2019. Fyra av totalt tolv resultatomrÃ¥den Ã¤r sÃ¤rskilt relevanta fÃ¶r den svenska strategin: god samhÃ¤llstyrning mÃ¤nskliga rÃ¤ttigheter gender; vÃ¥ld mot kvinnor och barn; kvinnligt deltagande och politiskt ledarskp; samt ekonomisk tillvÃ¤xt och sysselsÃ¤ttning. Den svenska strategin identifierar kvinnor, barn och ungdomar som prioriterade mÃ¥lgrupper vilket ocksÃ¥ reflekteras vÃ¤l i de omrÃ¥den fÃ¶r stÃ¶d som Sida valt. n nUNDAP II Ã¤r helt i linje med givarnas s k Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) och med Tanzanias nationella visioner (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). UNDAP II Ã¤r ocksÃ¥ utvecklad i linje med Tanzanias femÃ¥rsplan 2015 16 - 2020 21 och med de globala hÃ¥llbarhets- och utvecklingsmÃ¥len.  Programmet bidrar till FN:s fokus pÃ¥ fÃ¶rbÃ¤ttrade resultat och samstÃ¤mmighet genom att sammanfÃ¶ra ett 20-tal FN-organs planering, budgetering och rapportering i ett gemensamt resultatramverk fÃ¶r Tanzania. UNDAP II minskar dÃ¤rfÃ¶r i viss utstrÃ¤ckning Ã¤ven dubbelarbete fÃ¶r nationella partner sÃ¥vÃ¤l som fÃ¶r FN organisationer. n nDet svenska stÃ¶det ska ges via One UN Fund, i linje med Sveriges politik att stÃ¶dja ett sammanhÃ¥llet och mer effektivt FN-arbete i lÃ¤nderna (FN-reformen Delivering as One, DaO). UNDP Ã¤r det av FN utsedda FN-organ som administrerar One UN Fund (genom UNDP-kontoret i Dar es Salaam och huvudkontoret i New York), och UN Resident Coordinator  (UNRC) FN:s hÃ¶gste representant i Tanzania, varfÃ¶r bÃ¥da dessa stÃ¥r som FN:s undertecknande av SAA med Sida. I linje med Sveriges resultatstrategi fÃ¶r Tanzania kommer stÃ¶det inte att gÃ¥ generellt till UNDAP, utan som Ã¶ronmÃ¤rkt till de fyra nÃ¤mnda resultatomrÃ¥dena. n nMedlen kommer att fÃ¶rdelas enligt nedan till fÃ¶ljande resultatomrÃ¥den: n- Ekonomisk tillvÃ¤xt och anstÃ¤llning: 125 000 000 SEK   n- God samhÃ¤llsstyrning och mÃ¤nskliga rÃ¤ttigheter: 82 500 000 SEK  n- Kvinnors politiska deltagande: 50 000 000 SEK n- VÃ¥ld mot kvinnor och barn: 42 500 000 SEK, @xml:lang: SV, @type: 2,  narrative: : The United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAPII) in Tanzania is designed to strengthen the coherence and effectiveness of the UN system at national level, as a contribution to Tanzanias work for sustainable poverty reduction and the realization of human rights. nThe broad operations correspond to several of the goals stated in the results strategy for Swedish development cooperation with Tanzania for the period 2013-2019. UNDAPII results are grouped under four inter-related, mutually dependent themes which acknowledge that Inclusive Growth requites a Healthy Nation, which is Resilient to shocks both (natural and man-made) within a context of transparent and accountable Governance. These four thematic areas are divide into 12 outcomes and 39 outputs. Four out of a total of 12 outcomes in UNDAPII are particularly relevant to the Swedish strategy namely; (1)  xa0good governance and human rights (2) gender; violence against women and children; (3) female participation and political leadership (4) economic growth and employment. The Swedish strategy identifies women, children and young people as priority target groups. nThe program also contributes to the UNs focus on improved results and coherence by bringing together about 20 UN agencies planning, budgeting and reporting in a joint performance framework for Tanzania. UNDAP II therefore decreases to some extent duplication of work for national partners as well as for UN organizations. nThe support is earmarked for the four mentioned results areas a short description is provided below: nOUTCOME: ECONOMIC GROWTH AND EMPLOYMENT  The Outcome Statement: The economy is increasingly transformed for greater pro-poor inclusiveness, competivness and improved opportunities for decent and productive employment. The aim is to promote economic growth which is inclusive, specifically for pro-poor and provides opportunities for decent and productive employment, in particular for women and youth on both mainland and Zanzibar.   OUTCOME: DEMOCRATIC GOVERNACE, HUMAN RIGHTS AND GENDER EQUAILTY  The Outcome statement: National Governance is more effective, transparent, accountable and inclusive.  The aim is to strengthen Parliament, Government, Ministries, MDAs and LGAs (and other stakeholders) capacities to improve good governance, accountability, the rule of law and access to justice and increase respect, protection and fulfilment for human rights, both on mainland and Zanzibar. This is both influencing the normative agenda as well as providing technical assistance, help with policy coordination, planning capacity, skills development etc.   OUTCOME: VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN AND CHILDREN  The Outcome statement: Enhanced prevention of and response to violence against women and children. The aim is to intensify efforts to prevent and respond to violence against women across a range of initiatives on both the mainland and Zanzibar. This will be done by encompassing legislative and policy measures, more effective generation and utilisation of data, expansion of social Welfare case management and referrals to other service providers, addressing harmful cultural norms and practices whilst reinforcing positive practices at household and community level.   OUTCOME: WOMENÂ´S POLITICAL PARTICIPATION AND LEADERSHIP  The Outcome Statement: Women and Girls increasingly participate in political and public life and are elected to leadership positions. The aim is to support national institutions to promote accountable and transparent governance on both the Mainland and Zanzibar. Initiatives will strengthen the performance of core institutions, enhancing civic participation in policy formulation and public access to information, establishing a robust evidence base for decision making, facilitating compliance with commitments to international human rights norms and standards, and improving access to a more responsive justice system.

UNDAPII results are grouped under four inter-related, mutually dependent themes which acknowledge that Inclusive Growth requites a Healthy Nation, which is Resilient to shocks both (natural and man-made) within a context of transparent and accountable Governance. These four thematic areas are divide into 12 outcomes and 39 outputs. Four out of a total of 12 outcomes in UNDAPII are particularly relevant to the Swedish strategy namely; (1)  xa0good governance and human rights (2) gender; violence against women and children; (3) female participation and political leadership (4) economic growth and employment. The Swedish strategy identifies women, children and young people as priority target groups. nThe program also contributes to the UNs focus on improved results and coherence by bringing together about 20 UN agencies planning, budgeting and reporting in a joint performance framework for Tanzania. The aim is to promote economic growth which is inclusive, specifically for pro-poor and provides opportunities for decent and productive employment, in particular for women and youth on both mainland and Zanzibar.   OUTCOME: DEMOCRATIC GOVERNACE, HUMAN RIGHTS AND GENDER EQUAILTY  The Outcome statement: National Governance is more effective, transparent, accountable and inclusive.  The aim is to strengthen Parliament, Government, Ministries, MDAs and LGAs (and other stakeholders) capacities to improve good governance, accountability, the rule of law and access to justice and increase respect, protection and fulfilment for human rights, both on mainland and Zanzibar. This is both influencing the normative agenda as well as providing technical assistance, help with policy coordination, planning capacity, skills development etc.   OUTCOME: VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN AND CHILDREN  The Outcome statement: Enhanced prevention of and response to violence against women and children. The aim is to intensify efforts to prevent and respond to violence against women across a range of initiatives on both the mainland and Zanzibar. This will be done by encompassing legislative and policy measures, more effective generation and utilisation of data, expansion of social Welfare case management and referrals to other service providers, addressing harmful cultural norms and practices whilst reinforcing positive practices at household and community level.   OUTCOME: WOMENÂ´S POLITICAL PARTICIPATION AND LEADERSHIP  The Outcome Statement: Women and Girls increasingly participate in political and public life and are elected to leadership positions. The aim is to support national institutions to promote accountable and transparent governance on both the Mainland and Zanzibar. Initiatives will strengthen the performance of core institutions, enhancing civic participation in policy formulation and public access to information, establishing a robust evidence base for decision making, facilitating compliance with commitments to international human rights norms and standards, and improving access to a more responsive justice system.

Four out of a total of 12 outcomes in UNDAPII are particularly relevant to the Swedish strategy namely; (1)  xa0good governance and human rights (2) gender; violence against women and children; (3) female participation and political leadership (4) economic growth and employment. The Swedish strategy identifies women, children and young people as priority target groups. nThe program also contributes to the UNs focus on improved results and coherence by bringing together about 20 UN agencies planning, budgeting and reporting in a joint performance framework for Tanzania. UNDAP II therefore decreases to some extent duplication of work for national partners as well as for UN organizations. nThe support is earmarked for the four mentioned results areas a short description is provided below: nOUTCOME: ECONOMIC GROWTH AND EMPLOYMENT  The Outcome Statement: The economy is increasingly transformed for greater pro-poor inclusiveness, competivness and improved opportunities for decent and productive employment. The aim is to promote economic growth which is inclusive, specifically for pro-poor and provides opportunities for decent and productive employment, in particular for women and youth on both mainland and Zanzibar.   OUTCOME: DEMOCRATIC GOVERNACE, HUMAN RIGHTS AND GENDER EQUAILTY  The Outcome statement: National Governance is more effective, transparent, accountable and inclusive.  The aim is to strengthen Parliament, Government, Ministries, MDAs and LGAs (and other stakeholders) capacities to improve good governance, accountability, the rule of law and access to justice and increase respect, protection and fulfilment for human rights, both on mainland and Zanzibar. This is both influencing the normative agenda as well as providing technical assistance, help with policy coordination, planning capacity, skills development etc.   OUTCOME: VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN AND CHILDREN  The Outcome statement: Enhanced prevention of and response to violence against women and children. The aim is to intensify efforts to prevent and respond to violence against women across a range of initiatives on both the mainland and Zanzibar. This will be done by encompassing legislative and policy measures, more effective generation and utilisation of data, expansion of social Welfare case management and referrals to other service providers, addressing harmful cultural norms and practices whilst reinforcing positive practices at household and community level.   OUTCOME: WOMENÂ´S POLITICAL PARTICIPATION AND LEADERSHIP  The Outcome Statement: Women and Girls increasingly participate in political and public life and are elected to leadership positions. The aim is to support national institutions to promote accountable and transparent governance on both the Mainland and Zanzibar. Initiatives will strengthen the performance of core institutions, enhancing civic participation in policy formulation and public access to information, establishing a robust evidence base for decision making, facilitating compliance with commitments to international human rights norms and standards, and improving access to a more responsive justice system.

Description: NRC is Norwayâ€™s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida s Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC s capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida s humanitarian unit s annual budget appropriation which is substantial. nThe objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. nNRCâ€™s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. xa0Sida s Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC s method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). nMore specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras El Salvador Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. nAs an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: xa026% for Shelter and settlements, xa020% for xa0 Education, xa017% for Livelihoods and Food Security, xa014% for ICLA, xa09% for WASH, xa03% for Camp Management and xa011% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. nThe good scores of NRC in ITAD s evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. nDescribing NRC s activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC s work. xa0 nSHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC s expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in xa0protracted displacement situations. nLIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. That was a contribution to reduce dependency on aid, prevent criminality and violence, enhance social cohesion and at the same time preparing the way for durable solutions to displacement situation. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life xa0and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten xa0livelihoods and individuals  and households  abilities to earn a living. nICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one s rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. Advising on divorce procedures, supporting women to claim their rights while separating from men they had been married to in early marriage arrangements, was a significant work of NRC s lawyers. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to people to claim xa0and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative xa0dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity xa0documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge xa0around migration laws. Specific assistance to women and children as they may face xa0particular obstacles in accessing their rights. nEDUCATION: Children and youth lose years of education due to displacement. NRC works for reintegrating students in schools by helping them catching up lost grades faster. NRC has been training teachers and school personnel in Burundi to absorb the additional numbers of returnee youth who were Burundian refugees born in Tanzania that are enrolling in ill-prepared Burundian schools, at the best interest of the students, including protection aspects. Students had to be assisted for shifting overnight from Kiswahili and English-language curriculas to Kirundi and French-language curriculas. By doing that NRC, not only restaures education rights, but contributes to the local social cohesion. NRC is involved in the global Education Cannot Wait through advocacy. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to children and youth to complete a full cycle of basic education xa0with particular focus on those who are out of school or have had their education xa0interrupted. Provision of technical and vocational training for young adults. nCAMP MANAGEMENT: NRC showed further its protection work to Sida in Azraq and Zaatari refugee camps in Jordan, designed for accommodating social cases, un-documented individuals and alleged security threats, including un-accompanied minors, who could not be left free in the society according to the authorities. NRC would turn the experience of detention, in the middle of nowhere, desertic in fact, less depressing by upgrading shelter conditions, and providing education services, vocational training and psychosocial support, including assisting refugees to negotiate temporary exit permits. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Camp management, in and outside of camp settings. Camp xa0management core functions include coordinating and monitoring assistance and xa0protection, setting up and supporting governance and community participation xa0mechanisms, managing and disseminating information, providing multisector feedback xa0mechanisms, and maintaining infrastructure. nWASH: Five year into their displacement situation, Syrian refugees in Lebanon were still provided with 15 L person day drinkable water through costly water-trucking deliveries serving around 285,000 people living in thousands of informal tented settlements (ITS) of the Bekaa valley. Central authorities were blocking any improvements, like drilling wells, that would result in permanenting the refugee settlements in the country or giving the refugees the hope that they have a future in Lebanon. NRC managed to negotiate with communal councils, eager to improve their own infrastructures needing maintainance since the Civil War, that certain settlements along main roads would be connected to the local water systems. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of infrastructre for xa0water and sanitation, and information dissemination on good hygiene practices. nSida has evidence that NRC is aligning fully its own response strategies on the HRPs, which is a condition for receiving Sida s funding. NRC is usually an active stakeholder of the process of elaborating such plans, inter alia through its engagement in participating in or co-leading clusters of the local humanitarian system (potentially in its core competencies sectors) depending on locations, and through hosting NGO coordination forums. xa0 nRRM Allocation 2021 nIncluded in this contribution, it is proposed to support NRC s capacity to address new emerging humanitarian needs in rapid onset crises. Sida s funding Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) allocation to NRC will enable NRC to react very fast to new disasters when they strike. It may provide seed funding to larger response programmes and catalyze more resources, complementing as well the resources that the flexibility of PBA provides for re-allocating them in such circumstances, when possible. In 2020, NRC tapped into its 50 MSEK allocation 15 times, replenished once, until it was exhausted, intervening in 13 countries where NRC had presence in the context of sudden displacement situations, floods, droughts and socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 on displaced and vulnerable households. The assistance provided consisted generally in protection services and assistance delivered in form of cash, vouchers, and in-kind life-saving commodities, in the areas of shelter, basic assistance kits, hygiene promotion and psychosocial support. In 2021, NRC will undertake similar interventions with the RRM allocation with an initial 40 MSEK funding from Sida. RRM interventions are considered as projects, implemented over a 3 to 6 month period, with a 3 MSEK budget in average. The ceiling is 5 MSEK, while the bottom budget is 2 MSEK, but exceptions can be justified case by case. nMethod- and capacity-building projects nIncluded in this contribution, NRC has proposed to Sida to support Method- and capacity-building projects that will contribute to improve the global humanitarian system and coordination & advocacy forums at the national level. n- Strengthening global protection policy for displacement communities is a project that Sida is willing to prioritize as it xa0focuses on ensuring effective integration of protection across NRC programming and improvements to global humanitarian protection policy by translating concepts into concrete actionable outcomes. This project aims at ensuring that protection is foundational to all NRC work through the â€˜Safe Programmingâ€™ framework defining minimum commitments for NRC s operations, and at supporting the full realisation of the right of freedom of movement in safety and dignity for displacement-affected persons, in programmes for the protection of civilians, for durable solutions and for migrants in  refugee-like  situations. n- Becoming the leading displacement organization in hard to reach areas (H2R) is a project that will be supported in 2021 by Sida. It addresses the growing complexity of operating environments by investing in in-depth understanding of contexts against the backdrop of shifting international norms and the rise of new tech solutions to ensure timely and appropriate responses. NRC wants to xa0ensure that displacement-affected individuals considered hard-to-reach have better access to assistance and protection, by enhancing NRC s ability to access multiple geographical and cultural H2R contexts, by delivering high quality and sustained programming in H2R areas and by advocating for the rights of people affected by displacement in H2R areas. n- Sida s support to NRC s CashCap will be continued in 2021. The project ensures that humanitarian development agencies and national actors have sufficient and sustained expertise to design and implement cash and market-based response (CMBR) in an effective and coordinated manner. NRC intends to ensure global rapid deployment capacity for the initial days of a sudden onset emergency and to enable the systematic consideration of cash and voucher assistance as part of the initial response analysis. NRC will facilitate knowledge exchange, provide technical backstop and support to CashCap roster members on deployment, and improve sustainability between CashCap expert and cash community by sharing information, promoting continuity and encouraging to take ownership by the cash community. n- xa0NRCâ€™s Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) in Geneva will continue to be co-financed by Sida s humanitarian unit and Sida s unit for Global Cooperation on Environment in 2021. IDMC is a global leader in monitoring, reporting on and advocating for people displaced within their own country. It is known for its research publications and advocacy aiming at xa0generating evidence on all situations of internal displacement; building capacity to prevent and respond to the issue; and galvanising political commitment and action to drive positive change. For the second and probably last year, Sida s Unit for Global Cooperation on Environment will co-finance IDMC in 2021 together with the Humanitarian Unit, as IDMC analyzes displacement situation trends caused by climate change as well. IDMC adds great value to the evidence- and needs-based mobilization of resources for displacement situations. Its analysis and research are major contributions to the global and local advocacy agenda. n- NRC will be supported as well through this contribution for hosting local humanitarian coordination platforms where international and local NGOs cooperate for building up coordinated programmes, common advocacy agendas and for influencing the policy-making of authorities, the UN, donors and other partners. These forums play a key role in localizing the response, offering coordination services, training and partnership opportunities to the local NGO community. They play as well an important role for INGOs in addressing administrative and access obstacles that they may face with authorities for establishing themselves and obtaining visas and work permits. The Jordan INGO Forum and the Libya INGO Forum will be supported through this contribution. xa0NRC s active engagement in the local NGO forums, sometimes by hosting them with Sida s support (DRC, Palestine (AIDA), Jordan, Libya, Lebanon until (2019)), demonstrates NRC s commitment to aid effectiveness and collective action regarding humanitarian coordination and advocacy. n- Furthermore, it is proposed to continue co-financing for a last year the West Bank Protection Consortium (WBPC) with the Swedish General Consulate in Jerusalem and other donors. It is a strategic partnership between DG ECHO, 10 European States and 5 INGOs providing protection and assistance to Palestinians at risk of forcible transfer in the West Bank due to recurrent violations of international law. The project addresses the protection needs of persons and communities of concern through a multi-sector approach that reduces vulnerabilities, builds capacities and responds to threats. The Consulate has established a 3 year partnership 2021-2023 with NRC (#14571, 39 MSEK) for that project. The WBPC project, and the NGO platform AIDA, supported so far by Sida s humanitarian unit, will be funded by Sweden s development cooperation strategy for Palestine, integrated in that contribution., @xml:lang: EN}]}, {@type: 1,  narrative: [{: Norwegian Refugee Council - Norska flyktingrÃ¥det (NRC) - har ansÃ¶kt om ett fÃ¶rnyat partnerskap med Sida 2021-2025. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRCs programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus. n nNRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.  n nThe interventionâ€™s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sidaâ€™s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR,  etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach â€“ PBA). n nHumanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus nNRCs catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRCs advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRCs analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRCs portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Swedens development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.  n n1.2 MSEK is granted in June 2021 for supporting the IASCs review of the implementation of the IASC protection policy, through a 10 month consultancy hosted by NRC. n n40 MSEK are granted to NRC in Colombia and Venezuela regions (5+5 MSEK), Mali (5 MSEK), Mozambique (7.5 MSEK), Niger (7.5 MSEK) and Syria (10 MSEK) in June 2021 as reserve allocations to escalating and or under-funding crises. Mozambique is a new context for NRC. n n65 MSEK are granted to NRC in Dr Congo (10 MSEK), South Sudan (10 MSEK), Sudan (20 MSEK) and Syria (25 MSEK) in October 2021 as a end of the year allocation to escalating and underfunded crises., @xml:lang: EN}]}]

NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life xa0and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten xa0livelihoods and individuals  and households  abilities to earn a living. nICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one s rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. Advising on divorce procedures, supporting women to claim their rights while separating from men they had been married to in early marriage arrangements, was a significant work of NRC s lawyers. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to people to claim xa0and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative xa0dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity xa0documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge xa0around migration laws. Specific assistance to women and children as they may face xa0particular obstacles in accessing their rights. nEDUCATION: Children and youth lose years of education due to displacement. NRC works for reintegrating students in schools by helping them catching up lost grades faster. NRC has been training teachers and school personnel in Burundi to absorb the additional numbers of returnee youth who were Burundian refugees born in Tanzania that are enrolling in ill-prepared Burundian schools, at the best interest of the students, including protection aspects. Students had to be assisted for shifting overnight from Kiswahili and English-language curriculas to Kirundi and French-language curriculas. By doing that NRC, not only restaures education rights, but contributes to the local social cohesion. NRC is involved in the global Education Cannot Wait through advocacy. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to children and youth to complete a full cycle of basic education xa0with particular focus on those who are out of school or have had their education xa0interrupted. Provision of technical and vocational training for young adults. nCAMP MANAGEMENT: NRC showed further its protection work to Sida in Azraq and Zaatari refugee camps in Jordan, designed for accommodating social cases, un-documented individuals and alleged security threats, including un-accompanied minors, who could not be left free in the society according to the authorities. NRC would turn the experience of detention, in the middle of nowhere, desertic in fact, less depressing by upgrading shelter conditions, and providing education services, vocational training and psychosocial support, including assisting refugees to negotiate temporary exit permits. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Camp management, in and outside of camp settings. Camp xa0management core functions include coordinating and monitoring assistance and xa0protection, setting up and supporting governance and community participation xa0mechanisms, managing and disseminating information, providing multisector feedback xa0mechanisms, and maintaining infrastructure. nWASH: Five year into their displacement situation, Syrian refugees in Lebanon were still provided with 15 L person day drinkable water through costly water-trucking deliveries serving around 285,000 people living in thousands of informal tented settlements (ITS) of the Bekaa valley. Central authorities were blocking any improvements, like drilling wells, that would result in permanenting the refugee settlements in the country or giving the refugees the hope that they have a future in Lebanon. NRC managed to negotiate with communal councils, eager to improve their own infrastructures needing maintainance since the Civil War, that certain settlements along main roads would be connected to the local water systems. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of infrastructre for xa0water and sanitation, and information dissemination on good hygiene practices. nSida has evidence that NRC is aligning fully its own response strategies on the HRPs, which is a condition for receiving Sida s funding. NRC is usually an active stakeholder of the process of elaborating such plans, inter alia through its engagement in participating in or co-leading clusters of the local humanitarian system (potentially in its core competencies sectors) depending on locations, and through hosting NGO coordination forums. xa0 nRRM Allocation 2021 nIncluded in this contribution, it is proposed to support NRC s capacity to address new emerging humanitarian needs in rapid onset crises. Sida s funding Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) allocation to NRC will enable NRC to react very fast to new disasters when they strike. It may provide seed funding to larger response programmes and catalyze more resources, complementing as well the resources that the flexibility of PBA provides for re-allocating them in such circumstances, when possible. In 2020, NRC tapped into its 50 MSEK allocation 15 times, replenished once, until it was exhausted, intervening in 13 countries where NRC had presence in the context of sudden displacement situations, floods, droughts and socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 on displaced and vulnerable households. The assistance provided consisted generally in protection services and assistance delivered in form of cash, vouchers, and in-kind life-saving commodities, in the areas of shelter, basic assistance kits, hygiene promotion and psychosocial support. In 2021, NRC will undertake similar interventions with the RRM allocation with an initial 40 MSEK funding from Sida. RRM interventions are considered as projects, implemented over a 3 to 6 month period, with a 3 MSEK budget in average. The ceiling is 5 MSEK, while the bottom budget is 2 MSEK, but exceptions can be justified case by case. nMethod- and capacity-building projects nIncluded in this contribution, NRC has proposed to Sida to support Method- and capacity-building projects that will contribute to improve the global humanitarian system and coordination & advocacy forums at the national level. n- Strengthening global protection policy for displacement communities is a project that Sida is willing to prioritize as it xa0focuses on ensuring effective integration of protection across NRC programming and improvements to global humanitarian protection policy by translating concepts into concrete actionable outcomes. This project aims at ensuring that protection is foundational to all NRC work through the â€˜Safe Programmingâ€™ framework defining minimum commitments for NRC s operations, and at supporting the full realisation of the right of freedom of movement in safety and dignity for displacement-affected persons, in programmes for the protection of civilians, for durable solutions and for migrants in  refugee-like  situations. n- Becoming the leading displacement organization in hard to reach areas (H2R) is a project that will be supported in 2021 by Sida. It addresses the growing complexity of operating environments by investing in in-depth understanding of contexts against the backdrop of shifting international norms and the rise of new tech solutions to ensure timely and appropriate responses. NRC wants to xa0ensure that displacement-affected individuals considered hard-to-reach have better access to assistance and protection, by enhancing NRC s ability to access multiple geographical and cultural H2R contexts, by delivering high quality and sustained programming in H2R areas and by advocating for the rights of people affected by displacement in H2R areas. n- Sida s support to NRC s CashCap will be continued in 2021. The project ensures that humanitarian development agencies and national actors have sufficient and sustained expertise to design and implement cash and market-based response (CMBR) in an effective and coordinated manner. NRC intends to ensure global rapid deployment capacity for the initial days of a sudden onset emergency and to enable the systematic consideration of cash and voucher assistance as part of the initial response analysis. NRC will facilitate knowledge exchange, provide technical backstop and support to CashCap roster members on deployment, and improve sustainability between CashCap expert and cash community by sharing information, promoting continuity and encouraging to take ownership by the cash community. n- xa0NRCâ€™s Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) in Geneva will continue to be co-financed by Sida s humanitarian unit and Sida s unit for Global Cooperation on Environment in 2021. IDMC is a global leader in monitoring, reporting on and advocating for people displaced within their own country. It is known for its research publications and advocacy aiming at xa0generating evidence on all situations of internal displacement; building capacity to prevent and respond to the issue; and galvanising political commitment and action to drive positive change. For the second and probably last year, Sida s Unit for Global Cooperation on Environment will co-finance IDMC in 2021 together with the Humanitarian Unit, as IDMC analyzes displacement situation trends caused by climate change as well. IDMC adds great value to the evidence- and needs-based mobilization of resources for displacement situations. Its analysis and research are major contributions to the global and local advocacy agenda. n- NRC will be supported as well through this contribution for hosting local humanitarian coordination platforms where international and local NGOs cooperate for building up coordinated programmes, common advocacy agendas and for influencing the policy-making of authorities, the UN, donors and other partners. These forums play a key role in localizing the response, offering coordination services, training and partnership opportunities to the local NGO community. They play as well an important role for INGOs in addressing administrative and access obstacles that they may face with authorities for establishing themselves and obtaining visas and work permits. The Jordan INGO Forum and the Libya INGO Forum will be supported through this contribution. xa0NRC s active engagement in the local NGO forums, sometimes by hosting them with Sida s support (DRC, Palestine (AIDA), Jordan, Libya, Lebanon until (2019)), demonstrates NRC s commitment to aid effectiveness and collective action regarding humanitarian coordination and advocacy. n- Furthermore, it is proposed to continue co-financing for a last year the West Bank Protection Consortium (WBPC) with the Swedish General Consulate in Jerusalem and other donors. It is a strategic partnership between DG ECHO, 10 European States and 5 INGOs providing protection and assistance to Palestinians at risk of forcible transfer in the West Bank due to recurrent violations of international law. The project addresses the protection needs of persons and communities of concern through a multi-sector approach that reduces vulnerabilities, builds capacities and responds to threats. The Consulate has established a 3 year partnership 2021-2023 with NRC (#14571, 39 MSEK) for that project. The WBPC project, and the NGO platform AIDA, supported so far by Sida s humanitarian unit, will be funded by Sweden s development cooperation strategy for Palestine, integrated in that contribution., @xml:lang: EN}]}, {@type: 1,  narrative: [{: Norwegian Refugee Council - Norska flyktingrÃ¥det (NRC) - har ansÃ¶kt om ett fÃ¶rnyat partnerskap med Sida 2021-2025. NRC:s analyskapacitet Ã¤r en styrka som bidrar till att programmeringen anpassas till en nexus-ansats och den analys som genomfÃ¶rs av NRC:s internationella center fÃ¶r Ã¶vervakning av tvÃ¥ngsfÃ¶rflyttning (IDMC) Ã¤r av stor vikt fÃ¶r dessa analyser. 15 av de 26 kriser i NRC:s portfÃ¶lj som Sida finansierar avser lÃ¤nder dÃ¤r Sverige Ã¤ven bedriver  utvecklingssamarbete vilket Ã¶ppnar fÃ¶r mÃ¶jligheter till synergier med humanitÃ¤rt bistÃ¥nd. n nTillÃ¤gg beslut fÃ¶r att stÃ¶dja IASC Skydd Ã–versyn genom NRC bidar med ytterligare 1,2 mkr till NRC 2021. n nReservallokering 2021 bidrar med 40 mkr totalt till NRC  (Colombia och Venezuela regionalt 5 + 5 mkr, Mali 5 mkr, Mozambique 7,5 mkr, Niger 7,5 mkr, Syrien 10 mkr). NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out â€œthe Humanitarian Programme for 2021â€ in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine,  Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. The application includes provision of 40 million SEK to replenish the Rapid Response Mechanism funding instrument and 7 individual projects for method, capacity-building and coordination. n nThe objectives of NRCâ€™s intervention is to protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. NRCs principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021. n nNRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRCs programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus. n nNRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.  n nThe interventionâ€™s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sidaâ€™s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR,  etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach â€“ PBA). n nHumanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus nNRCs catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRCs advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRCs analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRCs portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Swedens development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.  n n1.2 MSEK is granted in June 2021 for supporting the IASCs review of the implementation of the IASC protection policy, through a 10 month consultancy hosted by NRC. n n40 MSEK are granted to NRC in Colombia and Venezuela regions (5+5 MSEK), Mali (5 MSEK), Mozambique (7.5 MSEK), Niger (7.5 MSEK) and Syria (10 MSEK) in June 2021 as reserve allocations to escalating and or under-funding crises. Mozambique is a new context for NRC. n n65 MSEK are granted to NRC in Dr Congo (10 MSEK), South Sudan (10 MSEK), Sudan (20 MSEK) and Syria (25 MSEK) in October 2021 as a end of the year allocation to escalating and underfunded crises., @xml:lang: EN}]}]

It wil develop local bylaws and protection mechanism, help women girls assert their rights and educate their peers, and influence attitudes of men and local leaders

Description: International Alert (IA) har ansÃ¶kt om finansiellt stÃ¶d till ett projekt med titeln Kvinnors smÃ¥skaliga grÃ¤nsÃ¶verskridande handel - MUPAKA SHAMBA LETU (vilket betyder grÃ¤nsen, vÃ¥r fÃ¶rsÃ¶rjning). Projektets mÃ¥l Ã¤r att stÃ¤rka kapaciteten hos kvinnor som Ã¤gnar sig Ã¥t smÃ¥skalig grÃ¤nsÃ¶verskridande handel i grÃ¤nsomrÃ¥dena mellan den Demokratiska Republiken Kongo (DRK), Rwanda och Burundi. Detta tillvÃ¤gagÃ¥ngssÃ¤tt ska gÃ¶ra det mÃ¶jligt fÃ¶r kvinnliga handlare att utmana den ojÃ¤mstÃ¤lldhet som bidrar till konflikter i deras samhÃ¤llen och den omgivande regionen, och att anvÃ¤nda deras inflytande fÃ¶r att frÃ¤mja stÃ¶rre social sammanhÃ¥llning och regionalt samarbete. n nFokus ligger pÃ¥ fyra grÃ¤nsomrÃ¥den: Uvira (DRC) -Gatumba (Burundi), Kamanyola (DRK) -Bugarama (Rwanda), Bukavu (DRC) -Kamembe (Rwanda) och Goma (DRC) -Gisenyi (Rwanda). Ekonomisk verksamhet och handel ska Ã¶ka fÃ¶rtroendet mellan de berÃ¶rda lÃ¤nderna, specifikt de samhÃ¤llen som ligger lÃ¤ngs de berÃ¶rda grÃ¤nserna. Projektet avser att bidra till att Ã¶ka antalet kvinnor som smÃ¥skaliga grÃ¤nsÃ¶verskridande nÃ¤ringsidkare, bygga upp deras kollektiva inflytande och ekonomiska makt, och frÃ¤mja mer inkluderande, och fredligt, engagemang mellan samhÃ¤llen Ã¶ver grÃ¤nserna. n nIA har fÃ¶r avsikt att engagera statliga institutioner, lokala myndigheter, lokala civilsamhÃ¤llesorganisationer och den privata sektorn (mikrofinansinstitut) fÃ¶r att skapa effektiva lÃ¶sningar pÃ¥ vissa konfliktproblem i de omrÃ¥den dÃ¤r projektet kommer att implementeras. n nIA kommer att implementera projektet tillsammans med Ã¥tta lokala partners. Bland dessa finns sex tidigare partners till IA frÃ¥n Tushiriki Wote Project: De valdes igen (av totalt 14) med tanke pÃ¥ deras kompetensomrÃ¥de. n nMÃ¥lgruppen avser 800 kvinnor som Ã¤gnar sig Ã¥t smÃ¥skalig grÃ¤nsÃ¶verskridande handel (100 per grÃ¤nsregion i Goma, Rubavu, Bukavu, Kamembe, Uvira, Gatumba, Kamanyola och Bugarama), 400 makar till dessa, 20 kvinnliga handelsfÃ¶reningar; 14 kooperativ; 60 smÃ¥ och medelstora fÃ¶retag - med sÃ¤rskilt fokus pÃ¥ kvinnliga smÃ¥ och medelstora fÃ¶retag, och 600 grÃ¤nskontrolltjÃ¤nstemÃ¤n., @xml:lang: SV, : International Alert (IA) has submitted a proposal for funding of a project titled â€œWomen cross border trade MUPAKA SHAMBA LETU (meaning â€œthe border our livelihoodâ€). The objective of the project is to strengthen the capacities of women small-scale cross-border traders in border areas of DRC, Rwanda, and Burundi. This approach should allow women traders to challenge the gender disparities which contributes to conflict in their communities and the surrounding region, and to use their influence to promote greater social cohesion and regional cooperation. n nFour borders are targeted: Uvira (DRC)-Gatumba (Burundi), Kamanyola (DRC)-Bugarama (Rwanda), Bukavu (DRC)-Kamembe (Rwanda) and Goma (DRC)-Gisenyi (Rwanda). Economic activities and trade will improve trust between the concerned countries specifically communities along these borders. The project intends to contribute to increasing the number of women small scale cross border traders,  to build their collective influence and economic power and to allow more inclusive and peaceful engagement between communities across borders.   n nIA will engage government institutions, local administrations, local CSOs and the private sector (microfinance institutions) to create effective solutions to certain problems of conflict in the areas where the project will operate. n nIA will manage the project together with eight local implementing partners. Among these, there are six previous partners to IA from the Tushiriki Wote Project: They were reselected (out of 14 in total) considering their field of expertise. n nTarget beneficiaries are 800 women small scale cross border traders (100 per border region at Goma, Rubavu, Bukavu, Kamembe, Uvira, Gatumba, Kamanyola and Bugarama);  400 spouses of small scale women cross border traders; 20 Women trader associations; 14 Cooperatives; 60 Small and Medium sized Enterprises (SMEs) â€“ with a specific focus on women SMEs and 600 Border officials, @type: 2,  narrative: : The main goal of this project is to contribute to a more inclusive society in border areas of DRC, Rwanda, and Burundi, which will in turn lead to a sustainable peace in the region. The Project focuses on strengthening the role that women traders living in these border communities can play in facilitating greater understanding between communities, through cross border trade. nThe proposal builds on previous IA work in the Great Lakes Region and earlier support from Sweden. nIn order to achieve this specific objective, IA will work on four key results areas. nThe first expected result: will focus on creating an enabling environment for women small scale cross border traders to strengthen and use their influence within the home and community, by addressing the socio-cultural norms that place men in a position of power over women in the household and community. nThe second expected result: Women small-scale cross-border traders in targeted border areas have increased economic resources and have the skills to use these resources to advocate for greater social cohesion and regional cooperation by the end of the Project. nThe third expected result is: business actors, including women cross border traders and SMEs, in target border areas engage more through increased networking and cooperation, and work together to use their influence in pushing for greater social cohesion, regional cooperation and peace across the region by the end of the Project nHaving strengthened women tradersâ€™ influence over decision making at the household and community levels and supported the way in which they engage with each other in cooperatives, associations and VSLA forums, the Project will, under this result 3, look to strengthen their influence, networks and impact on other key actors within cross border trade. nThe fourth expected result is that women small-scale cross-border traders, and border and customs officials in targeted border areas understand and have access to cross-border trade legislation, processes; women cross border traders use these resources to advocate for greater social cohesion, and regional cooperation and peace by the end of the project nIA has built up strong relationships with authorities and small-scale traders on all sides of the target areas and will, under this result, draw on these to strengthen information sharing on the trade agreements that have been signed and what these mean for traders and border customs officials in practice. n xa0 nThe Mupaka Shamba Letu Project will focus on 4 key border crossing points. These have been selected on the basis that they represent crossing points with some of the highest volume of trade and therefore the reach and impact of the Project is likely to be most significant. IA has been working in three of the four border regions for the past 4 years (Goma Rubavu, Bukavu Kamembe, and Uvira Gatumba). Through this, they have supported 600 women cross border traders to organise themselves into associations and cooperatives and strengthen their advocacy and leadership capacities, so that they are able to lead impactful advocacy campaigns at the border and provincial levels in particular and at the national and regional levels

Det kommer att bidra till sysselsÃ¤ttningsskapande och inkomstgenerering, sÃ¤rskilt inom jordbrukssektorn. n nMajoriteten av stÃ¶dmottagarna Ã¤r de minst utvecklande lÃ¤nderna, sÃ¤rskilt de afrikanska lÃ¤nderna.  STDF Ã¤r ett partnerskap med flera aktÃ¶rer som stÃ¶ds av ett antal bilaterala givare. Sida Ã¤r en av finansieringspartnerna.  n nSTDF har levererat goda resultat frÃ¥n tidigare Sida  stÃ¶d. Description: This project aims to help counteract increasing deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon by boosting near real-time monitoring capabilities of government, civil society, and local landholders
Organizations: ['ACA - Amazon Conservation Association', 'Norad - Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation', 'Norwegian Government', 'SPDA - Peruvian Society for Environmental Law']

Description: Achieve tangible improvements in forest and trade governance. EIA is also implementing the project in Peru
Organizations: ['AIDESEP - The Interethnic Association for the Development of the Peruvian Amazon', 'EIA - Environmental Investigation Agency', 'Norad - Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation', 'Norwegian Government']

Description: Recently Peru introduced the option of granting forest dwellers agroforestry concessions. These concessions could help Peru with curbing illegal deforestation at the same time as forest dwellers are secured a sustainable livelihood. GGGI, together with SPDA and ICRAFT, will work with naitonal and regional governments to pilot a model where agroforestry concessions are granted to forest dwellers, and these simultanously receive techncial assistance related to agroforestry farming and credit
Organizations: ['GGGI - Global Green Growth Institute', 'GGGI - Global Green Growth Institute', 'Norad - Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation', 'Norwegian Government']

Description: Access to reliable and safe energy is understood to be a prerequisite for sustainable development. This lack of access to energy constitutes a hindrance to the further social and economic development of the population living there. The project aims to contribute to the supply of electricity from renewable energies, in particular through solar home systems (SHS) and their loan financing. The lack of access to electricity (SDG 7) and to financing by the microfinance sector and other financing partners represent major obstacles to development. Scarce energy sources also have an impact on education and training as well as on the access to information of the population. The target group is predominantly the poor population, i.e. households and small businesses in rural and peri-urban areas, who either more or less do not have access to electricity or are affected by power cuts of 8 hours or more per day. The borrower of the subordinated loan (FZ-THB) is the Pakistan Microfinance Investment Company (PMIC). On behalf of the Federal Government of Germany, KfW participated in PMIC at the end of 2016 with equity of EUR 7 million or 13.2% of the voting rights and is also represented by a member of the Board of Directors and the credit risk committee. PMIC plans to set up a program for Access to energy through the financial sector as part of the expansion of PMIC s business strategy. Due to the innovative nature of such an approach in Pakistan, a Technical Assistance (TA) is foreseen to support PMICs and its Microfinance Partners, : Das Vorhaben zielt darauf ab, einen Beitrag zur Versorgung mit elektrischem Strom aus erneuerbaren Energien, im Besonderen durch Solar Home Systeme (SHS) und deren Kreditfinanzierung zu leisten.Der fehlende Zugang zu elektrischem Strom (SDG 7) und zu Finanzierung durch den Mikrofinanzsektor und andere Finanzierungspartner stellen ein wesentliches Entwicklungshemmnis dar. Description: The project will focus on reducing GBV in target communities, with a focus on women and girls  participation as well as facilitating GBV survivors protecting and access to safety and justice. The main purpose will be that GBV and gender discrimination are condemned in dominant social norms. Funds will be used to scale up EU project in Mansehra  which includes informal education (school campaigns)
Organizations: ['Kirkens N dhjelp', 'Norad - Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation', 'Norwegian Church Aid - local office', 'Norwegian Government']
