Description: NRC is Norwayâ€™s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida s Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC s capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida s humanitarian unit s annual budget appropriation which is substantial. nThe objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. nNRCâ€™s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. xa0Sida s Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC s method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). nMore specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras El Salvador Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. nAs an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: xa026% for Shelter and settlements, xa020% for xa0 Education, xa017% for Livelihoods and Food Security, xa014% for ICLA, xa09% for WASH, xa03% for Camp Management and xa011% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. nThe good scores of NRC in ITAD s evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. nDescribing NRC s activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC s work. xa0 nSHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC s expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in xa0protracted displacement situations. nLIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. That was a contribution to reduce dependency on aid, prevent criminality and violence, enhance social cohesion and at the same time preparing the way for durable solutions to displacement situation. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life xa0and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten xa0livelihoods and individuals  and households  abilities to earn a living. nICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one s rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. Advising on divorce procedures, supporting women to claim their rights while separating from men they had been married to in early marriage arrangements, was a significant work of NRC s lawyers. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to people to claim xa0and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative xa0dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity xa0documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge xa0around migration laws. Specific assistance to women and children as they may face xa0particular obstacles in accessing their rights. nEDUCATION: Children and youth lose years of education due to displacement. NRC works for reintegrating students in schools by helping them catching up lost grades faster. NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out â€œthe Humanitarian Programme for 2021â€ in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine,  Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. NRCs principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021. n nNRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRCs programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus. n nNRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.  n nThe interventionâ€™s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sidaâ€™s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR,  etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach â€“ PBA). n nHumanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus nNRCs catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRCs advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRCs analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRCs portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Swedens development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.  n n1.2 MSEK is granted in June 2021 for supporting the IASCs review of the implementation of the IASC protection policy, through a 10 month consultancy hosted by NRC. n n40 MSEK are granted to NRC in Colombia and Venezuela regions (5+5 MSEK), Mali (5 MSEK), Mozambique (7.5 MSEK), Niger (7.5 MSEK) and Syria (10 MSEK) in June 2021 as reserve allocations to escalating and or under-funding crises. Mozambique is a new context for NRC. n n65 MSEK are granted to NRC in Dr Congo (10 MSEK), South Sudan (10 MSEK), Sudan (20 MSEK) and Syria (25 MSEK) in October 2021 as a end of the year allocation to escalating and underfunded crises., @xml:lang: EN}]}]
Organizations: ['INTERNATIONAL NGO', 'NRC/Norwegian Refugee Council', 'Sweden', 'Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency']

Description: NRC is Norwayâ€™s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida s Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC s capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida s humanitarian unit s annual budget appropriation which is substantial. nThe objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. nNRCâ€™s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. xa0Sida s Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC s method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). nMore specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras El Salvador Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. nAs an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: xa026% for Shelter and settlements, xa020% for xa0 Education, xa017% for Livelihoods and Food Security, xa014% for ICLA, xa09% for WASH, xa03% for Camp Management and xa011% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. nThe good scores of NRC in ITAD s evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. nDescribing NRC s activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC s work. xa0 nSHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC s expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in xa0protracted displacement situations. nLIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. That was a contribution to reduce dependency on aid, prevent criminality and violence, enhance social cohesion and at the same time preparing the way for durable solutions to displacement situation. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life xa0and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten xa0livelihoods and individuals  and households  abilities to earn a living. nICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one s rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out â€œthe Humanitarian Programme for 2021â€ in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine,  Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. The application includes provision of 40 million SEK to replenish the Rapid Response Mechanism funding instrument and 7 individual projects for method, capacity-building and coordination. n nThe objectives of NRCâ€™s intervention is to protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. NRCs principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021. n nNRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRCs programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus. n nNRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.  n nThe interventionâ€™s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sidaâ€™s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach â€“ PBA). n nHumanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus nNRCs catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRCs advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRCs analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRCs portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Swedens development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.  n n1.2 MSEK is granted in June 2021 for supporting the IASCs review of the implementation of the IASC protection policy, through a 10 month consultancy hosted by NRC. n n40 MSEK are granted to NRC in Colombia and Venezuela regions (5+5 MSEK), Mali (5 MSEK), Mozambique (7.5 MSEK), Niger (7.5 MSEK) and Syria (10 MSEK) in June 2021 as reserve allocations to escalating and or under-funding crises. Mozambique is a new context for NRC. n n65 MSEK are granted to NRC in Dr Congo (10 MSEK), South Sudan (10 MSEK), Sudan (20 MSEK) and Syria (25 MSEK) in October 2021 as a end of the year allocation to escalating and underfunded crises., @xml:lang: EN}]}]

Description: NRC is Norwayâ€™s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida s Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC s capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida s humanitarian unit s annual budget appropriation which is substantial. nThe objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. nNRCâ€™s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. xa0Sida s Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC s method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). nMore specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras El Salvador Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. nAs an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: xa026% for Shelter and settlements, xa020% for xa0 Education, xa017% for Livelihoods and Food Security, xa014% for ICLA, xa09% for WASH, xa03% for Camp Management and xa011% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. nThe good scores of NRC in ITAD s evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. nDescribing NRC s activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC s work. xa0 nSHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC s expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in xa0protracted displacement situations. nLIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. That was a contribution to reduce dependency on aid, prevent criminality and violence, enhance social cohesion and at the same time preparing the way for durable solutions to displacement situation. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life xa0and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten xa0livelihoods and individuals  and households  abilities to earn a living. nICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one s rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. Advising on divorce procedures, supporting women to claim their rights while separating from men they had been married to in early marriage arrangements, was a significant work of NRC s lawyers. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to people to claim xa0and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative xa0dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity xa0documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge xa0around migration laws. Specific assistance to women and children as they may face xa0particular obstacles in accessing their rights. nEDUCATION: Children and youth lose years of education due to displacement. NRC works for reintegrating students in schools by helping them catching up lost grades faster. NRC has been training teachers and school personnel in Burundi to absorb the additional numbers of returnee youth who were Burundian refugees born in Tanzania that are enrolling in ill-prepared Burundian schools, at the best interest of the students, including protection aspects. Students had to be assisted for shifting overnight from Kiswahili and English-language curriculas to Kirundi and French-language curriculas. By doing that NRC, not only restaures education rights, but contributes to the local social cohesion. NRC is involved in the global Education Cannot Wait through advocacy. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to children and youth to complete a full cycle of basic education xa0with particular focus on those who are out of school or have had their education xa0interrupted. NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out â€œthe Humanitarian Programme for 2021â€ in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine,  Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. NRCs principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021. n nNRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRCs programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus. n nNRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.  n nThe interventionâ€™s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sidaâ€™s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR,  etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach â€“ PBA). n nHumanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus nNRCs catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRCs advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRCs analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRCs portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Swedens development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.  n n1.2 MSEK is granted in June 2021 for supporting the IASCs review of the implementation of the IASC protection policy, through a 10 month consultancy hosted by NRC. n n40 MSEK are granted to NRC in Colombia and Venezuela regions (5+5 MSEK), Mali (5 MSEK), Mozambique (7.5 MSEK), Niger (7.5 MSEK) and Syria (10 MSEK) in June 2021 as reserve allocations to escalating and or under-funding crises. Mozambique is a new context for NRC. n n65 MSEK are granted to NRC in Dr Congo (10 MSEK), South Sudan (10 MSEK), Sudan (20 MSEK) and Syria (25 MSEK) in October 2021 as a end of the year allocation to escalating and underfunded crises., @xml:lang: EN}]}]
Organizations: ['INTERNATIONAL NGO', 'NRC/Norwegian Refugee Council', 'Sweden', 'Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency']

Description: NRC is Norwayâ€™s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida s Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC s capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida s humanitarian unit s annual budget appropriation which is substantial. nThe objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. nNRCâ€™s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. xa0Sida s Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC s method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). nMore specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras El Salvador Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. nAs an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: xa026% for Shelter and settlements, xa020% for xa0 Education, xa017% for Livelihoods and Food Security, xa014% for ICLA, xa09% for WASH, xa03% for Camp Management and xa011% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. nThe good scores of NRC in ITAD s evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. nDescribing NRC s activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC s work. xa0 nSHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC s expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in xa0protracted displacement situations. nLIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. That was a contribution to reduce dependency on aid, prevent criminality and violence, enhance social cohesion and at the same time preparing the way for durable solutions to displacement situation. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life xa0and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten xa0livelihoods and individuals  and households  abilities to earn a living. nICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one s rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. Advising on divorce procedures, supporting women to claim their rights while separating from men they had been married to in early marriage arrangements, was a significant work of NRC s lawyers. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to people to claim xa0and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative xa0dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity xa0documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge xa0around migration laws. The application includes provision of 40 million SEK to replenish the Rapid Response Mechanism funding instrument and 7 individual projects for method, capacity-building and coordination. n nThe objectives of NRCâ€™s intervention is to protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. NRCs principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021. n nNRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRCs programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus. n nNRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.  n nThe interventionâ€™s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sidaâ€™s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR,  etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach â€“ PBA). n nHumanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus nNRCs catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRCs advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRCs analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRCs portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Swedens development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.  n n1.2 MSEK is granted in June 2021 for supporting the IASCs review of the implementation of the IASC protection policy, through a 10 month consultancy hosted by NRC. n n40 MSEK are granted to NRC in Colombia and Venezuela regions (5+5 MSEK), Mali (5 MSEK), Mozambique (7.5 MSEK), Niger (7.5 MSEK) and Syria (10 MSEK) in June 2021 as reserve allocations to escalating and or under-funding crises. Mozambique is a new context for NRC. n n65 MSEK are granted to NRC in Dr Congo (10 MSEK), South Sudan (10 MSEK), Sudan (20 MSEK) and Syria (25 MSEK) in October 2021 as a end of the year allocation to escalating and underfunded crises., @xml:lang: EN}]}]

Description: NRC is Norwayâ€™s largest international humanitarian organisation and widely recognised as a leading field-based displacement agency within the international humanitarian community. NRC is the INGO receiving the largest contribution from Sida s Humanitarian Unit to INGOs so far, based on experience of successful partnerships, NRC s capacities to respond at scale and its coverage of crises that Sida is prioritizing through the needs-based allocation approach. NRC receives approximately 8% of Sida s humanitarian unit s annual budget appropriation which is substantial. nThe objectives of NRC for 2021 can be summarized as follows: To protect the rights of displaced and vulnerable people during crisis, to provide assistance meeting their immediate humanitarian needs, to prevent further displacement and to contribute to durable solutions, and to provide expertise as a strategic partner to humanitarian systems and actors. It is expected, for 2021, that NRC will reach out approximately 7.26 million beneficiaries within the proposed country programme portfolio selected by Sida, to which the share of Sida will amount to around 8% according to its contribution in proportion to the total budget. In 2019, NRC reached globally 9.1 million persons in 33 crisis settings. nNRCâ€™s work is divided into three pillars: humanitarian assistance, advocacy and expert deployment. xa0Sida s Humanitarian Unit funding will continue prioritizing mainly the first pillar through funding of the humanitarian country programmes in line with HRPs and the RRPs and through the RRM funding. To some extent, Sida will support as well the second pillar of advocacy which is integrated in the humanitarian country programmes and implemented by NRC s method, thematic and capacity development projects supported by Sida. Sida will provide NRC with only a punctual support to the third pillar, through funding to CashCap which is deploying experts to the field for invigorating cash assistance working groups (17 in 2020 to 16 countries). nMore specifically, NRC will be supported for implementing humanitarian programmes in its respective areas of expertise in the settings that Sida and NRC have agreed upon to prioritize through this contribution: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, (plus Ecuador and Panama), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras El Salvador Mexico, Palestine, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen and Other. There are the largest refugee and internal displacement crises and cumulate around three quarters of the current global displacement caseload. These programmes will continue to be supported by Sida along the PBA regime of partnership initiated in 2016 and extended since then. nAs an indication, NRC distributed its total resources in 2019 within its core competencies as follows: xa026% for Shelter and settlements, xa020% for xa0 Education, xa017% for Livelihoods and Food Security, xa014% for ICLA, xa09% for WASH, xa03% for Camp Management and xa011% for Other. In 2021, NRC foresees to distribute its resources as follows: 21% for Education, 19% for Shelter and settlements, 19% for Livelihoods, 15% for ICLA, 12% for WaSH, 2% for Camp management, 1% for Advocacy. The COVID-19 socioeconomic impacts on displaced populations are partly motivating the increase in Education, Livelihoods, ICLA and WaSH. nThe good scores of NRC in ITAD s evaluation confirms for Sida that NRC is meeting its objectives and delivers quality humanitarian assistance and services, as expected. nDescribing NRC s activities within its core competencies would fill volumes. It is proposed here to provide few examples from field visit observations made between 2014 and 2020 in the Great Lakes and in the Levant that tell about NRC s work. xa0 nSHELTER: NRC may provide cash assistance, construction material, mobilize the community to build shelters for the most vulnerable unable to build them on their own, prevent evictions. In Lebanon, NRC identified very vulnerable and homeless refugee households, or about to be expelled by their landlords for not paying their rent due to poverty. NRC found unfinished housing constructions in the neighbourhood. NRC proposed to the owners to gradually finish the construction work of flats at NRC s expense but in exchange to accept to accommodate for free the vulnerable families for a year. The family would find shelter and a financial relief beneficial for the whole family as it would not have to pay for the rent, while the landlord would end up with an upgraded building. More interestingly, the refugee household would be identified in the neighborhood as a positive factor upgrading local housing standards, not down-grading the neighborhood socially. NRC documented that the protection of the household was improving ultimately, thanks to local social integration. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Facilitating access to shelter during emergency, as well as in xa0protracted displacement situations. nLIVELIHOODS: NRC masters cash assistance, to the point that it is used as an expert for helping other organizations to programme such interventions and for monitoring the outcomes of UN cash assistance systems on behalf of donors (CAMELEON Lebanon). In Bukavu (DRC), NRC created a vocational school that was handed over to the Governorate for training IDP youth and host community youth in developing different technical skills, including construction, IT, etc. that made them employeable on the labour market and enabled them to generate income. That was a contribution to reduce dependency on aid, prevent criminality and violence, enhance social cohesion and at the same time preparing the way for durable solutions to displacement situation. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of food assistance to prevent loss of life xa0and contribution to rehabilitation of local food and market systems to strenghten xa0livelihoods and individuals  and households  abilities to earn a living. nICLA: NRC is at its best in programmes where it helps refugees and IDPs to recreate the civil documentation that they have lost because of or during displacements. Lost documents may be birth certificates, property documents, certificates of marriage, heritage entitlements, diplomas, etc. Their absence exposes to violations, exploitation and abuse those who are deprived of such documents. Civil documentation, as observed in Jordan, is central for claiming one s rights, accessing services and preparing for the future. NRC assesses with individuals and families what is missing, advises how to access basic services and provides legal support to get back or replace documents, often across the border, with local lawyers. Syrian refugees would keep the ownership of properties that might have been confiscated if they were not claiming their rights on them timely thanks to NRC with valid property documents. Advising on divorce procedures, supporting women to claim their rights while separating from men they had been married to in early marriage arrangements, was a significant work of NRC s lawyers. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to people to claim xa0and exercise their rights through information, counselling, legal assistance, collaborative xa0dispute resolution, capacity building and advocacy to ensure access to legal identity xa0documentation, housing land and property rights, employment rights and knowledge xa0around migration laws. Specific assistance to women and children as they may face xa0particular obstacles in accessing their rights. nEDUCATION: Children and youth lose years of education due to displacement. NRC works for reintegrating students in schools by helping them catching up lost grades faster. NRC has been training teachers and school personnel in Burundi to absorb the additional numbers of returnee youth who were Burundian refugees born in Tanzania that are enrolling in ill-prepared Burundian schools, at the best interest of the students, including protection aspects. Students had to be assisted for shifting overnight from Kiswahili and English-language curriculas to Kirundi and French-language curriculas. By doing that NRC, not only restaures education rights, but contributes to the local social cohesion. NRC is involved in the global Education Cannot Wait through advocacy. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Support to children and youth to complete a full cycle of basic education xa0with particular focus on those who are out of school or have had their education xa0interrupted. Provision of technical and vocational training for young adults. nCAMP MANAGEMENT: NRC showed further its protection work to Sida in Azraq and Zaatari refugee camps in Jordan, designed for accommodating social cases, un-documented individuals and alleged security threats, including un-accompanied minors, who could not be left free in the society according to the authorities. NRC would turn the experience of detention, in the middle of nowhere, desertic in fact, less depressing by upgrading shelter conditions, and providing education services, vocational training and psychosocial support, including assisting refugees to negotiate temporary exit permits. NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Camp management, in and outside of camp settings. Camp xa0management core functions include coordinating and monitoring assistance and xa0protection, setting up and supporting governance and community participation xa0mechanisms, managing and disseminating information, providing multisector feedback xa0mechanisms, and maintaining infrastructure. nWASH: Five year into their displacement situation, Syrian refugees in Lebanon were still provided with 15 L person day drinkable water through costly water-trucking deliveries serving around 285,000 people living in thousands of informal tented settlements (ITS) of the Bekaa valley. Central authorities were blocking any improvements, like drilling wells, that would result in permanenting the refugee settlements in the country or giving the refugees the hope that they have a future in Lebanon. NRC managed to negotiate with communal councils, eager to improve their own infrastructures needing maintainance since the Civil War, that certain settlements along main roads would be connected to the local water systems. xa0NRC presents its works in this sector as follows: xa0Provision of infrastructre for xa0water and sanitation, and information dissemination on good hygiene practices. nSida has evidence that NRC is aligning fully its own response strategies on the HRPs, which is a condition for receiving Sida s funding. NRC is usually an active stakeholder of the process of elaborating such plans, inter alia through its engagement in participating in or co-leading clusters of the local humanitarian system (potentially in its core competencies sectors) depending on locations, and through hosting NGO coordination forums. xa0 nRRM Allocation 2021 nIncluded in this contribution, it is proposed to support NRC s capacity to address new emerging humanitarian needs in rapid onset crises. Sida s funding Rapid Response Mechanism (RRM) allocation to NRC will enable NRC to react very fast to new disasters when they strike. It may provide seed funding to larger response programmes and catalyze more resources, complementing as well the resources that the flexibility of PBA provides for re-allocating them in such circumstances, when possible. In 2020, NRC tapped into its 50 MSEK allocation 15 times, replenished once, until it was exhausted, intervening in 13 countries where NRC had presence in the context of sudden displacement situations, floods, droughts and socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 on displaced and vulnerable households. The assistance provided consisted generally in protection services and assistance delivered in form of cash, vouchers, and in-kind life-saving commodities, in the areas of shelter, basic assistance kits, hygiene promotion and psychosocial support. In 2021, NRC will undertake similar interventions with the RRM allocation with an initial 40 MSEK funding from Sida. RRM interventions are considered as projects, implemented over a 3 to 6 month period, with a 3 MSEK budget in average. The ceiling is 5 MSEK, while the bottom budget is 2 MSEK, but exceptions can be justified case by case. nMethod- and capacity-building projects nIncluded in this contribution, NRC has proposed to Sida to support Method- and capacity-building projects that will contribute to improve the global humanitarian system and coordination & advocacy forums at the national level. n- Strengthening global protection policy for displacement communities is a project that Sida is willing to prioritize as it xa0focuses on ensuring effective integration of protection across NRC programming and improvements to global humanitarian protection policy by translating concepts into concrete actionable outcomes. This project aims at ensuring that protection is foundational to all NRC work through the â€˜Safe Programmingâ€™ framework defining minimum commitments for NRC s operations, and at supporting the full realisation of the right of freedom of movement in safety and dignity for displacement-affected persons, in programmes for the protection of civilians, for durable solutions and for migrants in  refugee-like  situations. n- Becoming the leading displacement organization in hard to reach areas (H2R) is a project that will be supported in 2021 by Sida. It addresses the growing complexity of operating environments by investing in in-depth understanding of contexts against the backdrop of shifting international norms and the rise of new tech solutions to ensure timely and appropriate responses. NRC wants to xa0ensure that displacement-affected individuals considered hard-to-reach have better access to assistance and protection, by enhancing NRC s ability to access multiple geographical and cultural H2R contexts, by delivering high quality and sustained programming in H2R areas and by advocating for the rights of people affected by displacement in H2R areas. n- Sida s support to NRC s CashCap will be continued in 2021. The project ensures that humanitarian development agencies and national actors have sufficient and sustained expertise to design and implement cash and market-based response (CMBR) in an effective and coordinated manner. NRC intends to ensure global rapid deployment capacity for the initial days of a sudden onset emergency and to enable the systematic consideration of cash and voucher assistance as part of the initial response analysis. NRC will facilitate knowledge exchange, provide technical backstop and support to CashCap roster members on deployment, and improve sustainability between CashCap expert and cash community by sharing information, promoting continuity and encouraging to take ownership by the cash community. n- xa0NRCâ€™s Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) in Geneva will continue to be co-financed by Sida s humanitarian unit and Sida s unit for Global Cooperation on Environment in 2021. IDMC is a global leader in monitoring, reporting on and advocating for people displaced within their own country. It is known for its research publications and advocacy aiming at xa0generating evidence on all situations of internal displacement; building capacity to prevent and respond to the issue; and galvanising political commitment and action to drive positive change. For the second and probably last year, Sida s Unit for Global Cooperation on Environment will co-finance IDMC in 2021 together with the Humanitarian Unit, as IDMC analyzes displacement situation trends caused by climate change as well. IDMC adds great value to the evidence- and needs-based mobilization of resources for displacement situations. Its analysis and research are major contributions to the global and local advocacy agenda. n- NRC will be supported as well through this contribution for hosting local humanitarian coordination platforms where international and local NGOs cooperate for building up coordinated programmes, common advocacy agendas and for influencing the policy-making of authorities, the UN, donors and other partners. These forums play a key role in localizing the response, offering coordination services, training and partnership opportunities to the local NGO community. They play as well an important role for INGOs in addressing administrative and access obstacles that they may face with authorities for establishing themselves and obtaining visas and work permits. The Jordan INGO Forum and the Libya INGO Forum will be supported through this contribution. xa0NRC s active engagement in the local NGO forums, sometimes by hosting them with Sida s support (DRC, Palestine (AIDA), Jordan, Libya, Lebanon until (2019)), demonstrates NRC s commitment to aid effectiveness and collective action regarding humanitarian coordination and advocacy. n- Furthermore, it is proposed to continue co-financing for a last year the West Bank Protection Consortium (WBPC) with the Swedish General Consulate in Jerusalem and other donors. It is a strategic partnership between DG ECHO, 10 European States and 5 INGOs providing protection and assistance to Palestinians at risk of forcible transfer in the West Bank due to recurrent violations of international law. The project addresses the protection needs of persons and communities of concern through a multi-sector approach that reduces vulnerabilities, builds capacities and responds to threats. The Consulate has established a 3 year partnership 2021-2023 with NRC (#14571, 39 MSEK) for that project. The WBPC project, and the NGO platform AIDA, supported so far by Sida s humanitarian unit, will be funded by Sweden s development cooperation strategy for Palestine, integrated in that contribution., @xml:lang: EN}]}, {@type: 1,  narrative: [{: Norwegian Refugee Council - Norska flyktingrÃ¥det (NRC) - har ansÃ¶kt om ett fÃ¶rnyat partnerskap med Sida 2021-2025. NRC has applied as well to Sida for funding of 364.5 million SEK to carry out â€œthe Humanitarian Programme for 2021â€ in 26 humanitarian crisis settings: Afghanistan, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Honduras, El Salvador, Mexico, Palestine,  Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania Burundi, Uganda, Venezuela, Yemen. NRCs principled and clear advocacy has the potential to influence positively decision-makers and duty-bearers. NRC is planning to assist around 7,263,000 persons in 2021. n nNRC builds its programmes with people in the centre, in particular the displaced persons. As a rights-based organization, it delivers assistance with the aim to protect the most vulnerable from harm and to help them rebuild their lives. NRC always prepares therefore for durable solutions in delivering humanitarian assistance. NRC even integrates humanitarian mediation in its programmes at the community level wherever it can contribute to the peaceful solution to conflicts. NRCs programming follows obviously the triple humanitarian-development-peace nexus. n nNRC will implement the intervention mainly by itself, through its 7,700 staff members and 7,000 volunteers mobilized within the affected communities.  n nThe interventionâ€™s tentative total budget is 4 263 200 000 Norwegian krona (NOK), that the organisation is financing with Sidaâ€™s funding in a proportion of 8% approximately. Other donors, like the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, DG ECHO, UNHCR,  etc. are the largest contributors, besides a dozen of other donors in agreement with NRC. Sida provides NRC with the opportunity to allocate resources flexibly within individual country programmes (Programme-Based Approach â€“ PBA). n nHumanitarian-Development-Peace Nexus nNRCs catalytic support for coordination and capacity building contributes greatly to the link between humanitarian aid, development and peace. NRCs advocacy work and activities enable, at least contribute to, sustainable solutions for refugees and displaced people in a significant way in cooperation with other actors. In the long run, the NRC will reduce humanitarian needs. The NRC prioritizes self-sufficiency in its programs. The NRCs analysis capability, not least through its Internal Displacement Monitoring Center (IDMC), is an advantage for relevant programming according to the nexus orientations. Among the 26 crises in NRCs portfolio that Sida prioritizes, there are 15 where Sida implements Swedens development strategies in synergy with humanitarian aid.  n n1.2 MSEK is granted in June 2021 for supporting the IASCs review of the implementation of the IASC protection policy, through a 10 month consultancy hosted by NRC. n n40 MSEK are granted to NRC in Colombia and Venezuela regions (5+5 MSEK), Mali (5 MSEK), Mozambique (7.5 MSEK), Niger (7.5 MSEK) and Syria (10 MSEK) in June 2021 as reserve allocations to escalating and or under-funding crises. Mozambique is a new context for NRC. n n65 MSEK are granted to NRC in Dr Congo (10 MSEK), South Sudan (10 MSEK), Sudan (20 MSEK) and Syria (25 MSEK) in October 2021 as a end of the year allocation to escalating and underfunded crises., @xml:lang: EN}]}]

Description: The project seeks to fulfill five key objectives: n1. Support national longitudinal quantitative and qualitative impact evaluation of government-owned and implemented cash transfer and integrated social protection programmes in the region in order to: understand programme impacts, and the role of design and implementation features and pathways through which impacts are achieved; n2. Generate evidence that supports national efforts to build risk-informed and shock-responsive social protection systems, including national registries and delivery mechanisms that facilitate effective and rapid vertical and horizontal expansions; n3. Support national efforts to build investment cases and identify sustainable financing for building statutory cash transfer and social protection programmes; n4. Undertake cross-country and cross-regional analysis to respond to evidence gaps on social transfer programmes and social protection systems in the region n5. Facilitate mechanisms for learning and exchange among regional policy makers, implementers, researchers and civil society â€“ through workshops, web resources, public data availability, and open-access publications. nProposed outputs will include primary data collection, reports, manuscripts for peer-reviewed publication, policy and research briefs and infographics animations to translate findings, engagement with policymakers, and dissemination via social media, peer-reviewed journals, capacity building for African researchers and international conference presentations. nComments xa0 nThere is ongoing work in Ethiopia, Tanzania and Burkina Faso. These three countries are earmarked to receive continued support for 2021 and 2022. xa0 nIn the East and Southern African region there is more interest in evidence related to the role of design and implementation in achieving impacts. In West and Central Africa, where social protection programmes are not as widely established, basic impact evaluations are is still required to make the case for investing in cash transfers and social protection programmes. nProposed topics for potential secondary analyses (including cross-country comparisons) and in-depth papers: Impacts of cash-transfer programmes on education, time use and safe-transition to adulthood using data from Malawi, Ethiopia and Ghana. Impacts of cash transfers on food-group elasticities. Comparison of social cash transfer beneficiaries with ultra-poor populations within countries nTopics of other outputs related to dissemination (briefs, blogs, social media, presentations) will be determined by the aforementioned data collections and papers finalized, as well as invitations received related to international meetings on an annual basis. nThe Transfer Project workshop (held approximately every two years) is a key capacity building activity for researchers, policymakers, and development partners alike and is jointly convened by all three Transfer Project partners. The workshop provides a space for the researchers, practitioners, policymakers, national and international partners to engage with each other and helps to increase the understanding of evidence. It also provides an impetus for other countries to demand rigorous evidence generation in their own countries, or to study previously understudied questions in their own context by exposure to what researchers are doing elsewhere. xa0 nFinally, UNICEF Innocenti will convene sub-regional webinars that promote evidence exchange between neighboring countries. STDF Ã¤r ett partnerskap med flera aktÃ¶rer som stÃ¶ds av ett antal bilaterala givare. Sida Ã¤r en av finansieringspartnerna.  n nSTDF har levererat goda resultat frÃ¥n tidigare Sida  stÃ¶d. STDF har vÃ¤l utvecklade regler och fÃ¶reskrifter fÃ¶r att sÃ¤kerstÃ¤lla genomfÃ¶rande och uppfÃ¶ljning och rapportering av resultat. n  nDet Ã¥rliga totala budgetbehovet fÃ¶r genomfÃ¶randet av STDF-strategin ligger pÃ¥ cirka 70 miljoner SEK. Sidas bidrag Ã¤r 10 miljoner SEK per Ã¥r och resterande belopp finansieras av andra bilaterala och multi-laterala organisationer som Storbritannien, NederlÃ¤nderna, Norge och EU., @xml:lang: SV, : The  overall objective of the intervention is to contribute to capacity and knowledge development in the field of SPS (Sanitary and phyto-Sanitary) and to support countries  in their efforts to comply to international SPS norms and standards. SPS gaps remain one of the major challenges to agricultural trade, limiting opportunities for small-scale farmers, producers and traders and others to benefit. Description: Objectives nThe overall of objective of the contribution is increased financial inclusion especially for currently excluded groups (MIPYMES with a special focus on women and young) through the introduction and use of a guarantee fund in the sectors of commerce, production and services. xa0 nThe contribution is expected to have the indirect impact to increase the formal economy and xa0 financial inclusion contributing to economic development, promote green investments and environmentally sustainable businesses. xa0 nIn parallel the contribution will contribute to the development of new norms in public policy xa0 and national financial system that will allow for a more inclusive system with alternative mechanisms developed through the programme.  xa0 nTheory of Change nSetting up a guarantee fund, and sharing the risk of lending will increase the lending to other social lenders. With an increased capital and guarantee in the back (with set criteria to incentive that target groups are reached) the social lenders will expand their target group, reach more people and new groups such as more micro and small businesses including women and young as well as increase their knowledge of and hopefully aptitude to lend to these groups in the future. Through the guarantee and TA, PROFIN will promote the innovation of financial products adapted for the target groups and by increasing the access to finance micro and small companies will have a higher probability of surviving and prospering in their business, avoiding to have to go through informal channels with unfavourable conditions. In the long term it is expected that the intervention will increase the formality of the economy and decrease the vulnerability of the micro and small enterprises and with a long term impact of more formal jobs and reduced poverty. To ensure that the goal of increased access reaches the identified target groups and that the micro and small enterprises can make the most of it by having solid business plans and payment plans, a strong component of xa0 technical assistance and monitoring must accompany the guarantee. PROFIN, already a partner of the Embassy in the Inclusive markets program, will be responsible and agreement partner to the Embassy in this component. This will include a package of financial education at the loan taker level but also articulation between actors to build knowledge and trust at EIF and institutional level towards the target groups as well as advocacy for inclusive financial legal frameworks at national level. nBy conditioning the loans to certain environmental and gender standards it is also expected that the intervention will promote a more environmentally sustainable and less discriminatory business climate. xa0 nPROFIN is well placed to undertake this responsibility with a strong presence in rural areas, trust (at different levels), experience and innovation, @type: 1,  narrative: : Projektet riktar sig mot den hÃ¶ga informaliteten i den ekonomiska sektorn i Bolivia, den lÃ¥ga nivÃ¥n av finansiell integration och de svÃ¥righeter som mikrofÃ¶retag och smÃ¥ fÃ¶retag stÃ¥r infÃ¶r fÃ¶r att fÃ¥ tillgÃ¥ng till finansiering fÃ¶r sin verksamhet. Helvetas kommer att implementera projektet tillsammans med Swisscontact och Agua Tuya och kommer att samarbeta med kommuner, privat och offentlig sektor. n nInsatsens totala budget Ã¤r 49 140 000 SEK som helt tÃ¤cks av Sida, @xml:lang: SV, : Helvetas has applied to Sida for funding of 49 140 000 SEK million SEK to carry out the 0 waste in Bolivia programme during the period 2019-2022.  n nThe project aims to contribute to the management of solid waste in the country (along different levels, actors, public, social and private spheres), prioritizing; n- reduction in solid waste generation, n- promoting separation at source, as its use, before final disposal solutions. nThe approach adopted for this is â€œ0 wasteâ€: when the amount of waste (especially organic) that is buried in sanitary landfills or controlled dumps is minimized, then the generation of leachate and greenhouse gases is reduced. At the same time, increasing use allows less waste in final disposal, contributing to a longer useful life of the landfills and greater efficiency in the systems.  nThe expected result (impact) is: nHealth improved within populations of selected municipalities, by lower levels of environmental pollution. nThe main objective is to generate models of integrated solid waste management emphasizing use of waste under a circular economy approach. n nTo achieve this goal, four specific objectives have been established: n1) Improve households access to good quality and continued services of solid waste management, especially by increased waste collection coverage and a more efficient transportation. n2) Increase stakeholders reuse of waste in different kinds of contexts and city sizes, by establishing reuse systems for organic and recyclable types of waste and developing specific norms. n3) Strengthen the solid waste sector at national and local level applying cooperative institutional arrangements and developing institutional capacities. n4) Increase participation of households and institutions in integrated solid waste management activities by developing capacities, sharing and learning from experiences and raising awareness at different levels. n nThe project will build, along key actors, integral solid waste management models, stressing use under a circular economy approach, in three particular contexts: (i) major urban center as La Paz, (ii) intermediate city such as Tarija, and (iii) a joint solution for intermediate and small cities in the Chaco CruceÃ±o (Camiri, Boyuibe, Cuevo, Lagunillas and GutiÃ©rrez). The emphasis on waste reduction and reuse should report higher rates of use in the intervention areas.
